description: Low-light tolerant aroids with variegated foliage in shades of green, silver, pink, or red
commonExamples: Aglaonema commutatum (Chinese evergreen), A. pictum, A. 'Silver Bay', A. 'Red Siam'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil feels dry. Keep slightly more moist than other low-light plants but avoid soggy soil. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; low light is tolerated but may reduce color. Maintain 50-60% humidity. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer (20-20-20) diluted to half strength. Wipe leaves monthly with damp cloth to remove dust and improve photosynthesis. Repot every 2-3 years in spring when roots fill container. Prune yellowing leaves at base. Watch for spider mites in dry conditions.

description: Extremely low-light tolerant foliage plant in the Asparagaceae family, named for its ability to survive neglect. Includes various cultivars like variegated and speckled varieties.
commonExamples: Aspidistra elatior (Cast iron plant, Barroom plant), A. elatior 'Variegata' (Variegated cast iron plant), A. elatior 'Milky Way' (speckled variety)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Extremely forgiving of inconsistent watering and low light conditions. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Tolerates very low light but grows faster in bright indirect light. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot only when severely root-bound (every 5-7 years). Remove dead or yellowing leaves at base by cutting at soil level. Dust leaves occasionally. One of the most indestructible houseplants.

description: Corn plant with broad, arching leaves, can grow quite tall
commonExamples: Dracaena fragrans (Corn plant, Cornstalk dracaena), D. fragrans 'Massangeana'
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Use filtered, distilled, or rainwater to prevent brown leaf tips from fluoride and chlorine. Bright indirect to medium light preferred. Maintain 40-50% humidity. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer diluted to half strength. Wipe leaves monthly to remove dust. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container. Prune brown tips and remove yellowing lower leaves. Sensitive to drafts and temperature fluctuations.

description: Dragon tree with thin, arching leaves with red edges, very low-maintenance
commonExamples: Dracaena marginata (Dragon tree, Madagascar dragon tree)
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Use filtered, distilled, or rainwater to prevent brown leaf tips from fluoride and chlorine. Bright indirect light maintains red edge coloration. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Trim brown tips with clean scissors. Remove lower leaves as they yellow. Very low-maintenance once established.

description: Extremely easy-care trailing aroids in the Araceae family, excellent for beginners, includes many variegated varieties
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Pothos, Devil's ivy), Golden, Marble Queen, Neon, Jade, and many other varieties
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of neglect and inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent for beginners. Toxic to pets. One of the most popular houseplants.

description: Extremely low-maintenance succulents in the Asparagaceae family with upright sword-like leaves. Includes various cultivars with different leaf shapes and patterns.
commonExamples: Dracaena trifasciata (syn. Sansevieria trifasciata; Mother-in-law's tongue), D. trifasciata 'Laurentii', D. trifasciata 'Moonshine', D. trifasciata 'Black Gold', Dracaena angolensis (syn. Sansevieria cylindrica; cylindrical snake plant)
careTips: Water only when soil is completely dry (every 2-8 weeks depending on conditions). Very drought tolerant due to water storage in leaves. Bright indirect to direct light preferred; tolerates low light but grows slowly. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot only when pot breaks or plant becomes top-heavy (every 5-10 years). Remove dead leaves at base by pulling gently. Divide offsets when repotting. Overwatering is the main cause of death - when in doubt, wait longer.

description: Easy-care trailing plants in the Asparagaceae family that produce plantlets on stolons, excellent air purifiers. Includes various cultivars with different variegation patterns.
commonExamples: Chlorophytum comosum (Spider plant, Airplane plant, Ribbon plant), C. comosum 'Vittatum', C. comosum 'Variegatum', C. comosum 'Bonnie'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly moist but avoid overwatering which causes brown tips. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Remove plantlets when they develop roots (2-3 inches long) to propagate or reduce crowding. Trim brown tips with clean scissors. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container. Excellent air purifier. Watch for spider mites in dry conditions.

description: Drought-tolerant plants in the Asparagaceae family with sword-like leaves, can grow into small trees
commonExamples: Yucca elephantipes (Spineless yucca, Giant yucca), Y. aloifolia (Spanish bayonet, Dagger plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 3-5 years when roots fill container. Remove dead leaves at base. Can grow quite large - provide adequate space. Sharp leaf tips - handle with care.

description: Extremely low-maintenance plant in the Araceae family with glossy leaves and rhizomes that store water, virtually indestructible
commonExamples: Zamioculcas zamiifolia (ZZ plant, Zanzibar gem, Eternity plant), Z. zamiifolia 'Raven' (Raven ZZ)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Rhizomes store water making it extremely drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot - when in doubt, wait. Low to bright indirect light tolerated; grows faster in brighter light. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 2-3 years when rhizomes fill container. Wipe glossy leaves monthly to remove dust. Virtually indestructible - perfect for beginners.

description: Dark purple-black variety of ZZ plant, same easy-care as standard ZZ, new growth emerges green and darkens with age
commonExamples: Zamioculcas zamiifolia 'Raven' (Raven ZZ plant, Black ZZ), Z. zamiifolia (standard green ZZ), Z. zamiifolia 'Zenzi' (compact variety)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Rhizomes store water making it extremely drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot. Low to bright indirect light; new growth emerges green and darkens to purple-black with age. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Wipe glossy leaves monthly. Same easy-care as standard ZZ plant with striking dark foliage.

description: Tropical aroids with large, arrow-shaped leaves (elephant ears), many require high humidity and consistent moisture
commonExamples: Alocasia × amazonica 'Polly' (hybrid), A. macrorrhizos (Giant taro), A. zebrina (Zebra plant), A. longiloba
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. High humidity (60-80%) essential - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Maintain warm temperatures (65-80°F). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Mist leaves daily or use humidifier. Repot annually in spring with well-draining soil. Wipe large leaves monthly. Watch for spider mites. Some species go dormant in winter - reduce watering then.

description: Tropical aroids with colorful spathes and glossy foliage, long-lasting blooms
commonExamples: Anthurium andraeanum (Flamingo flower), A. crystallinum (Crystal anthurium), A. scherzerianum
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light encourages blooms. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks spring through fall with orchid or high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Remove spent flowers. Repot every 2 years in spring. Wipe glossy leaves monthly. Blooms last 2-3 months. Avoid cold drafts.

description: Tropical plants in the Araceae family with distinctive inflorescences (spathes and spadices), many are popular houseplants
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa (Swiss cheese plant), Philodendron, Epipremnum (Pothos), Anthurium, Alocasia, Spathiphyllum (Peace lily)
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Most prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) beneficial. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot when roots fill container. Wipe leaves monthly. Many are excellent air purifiers. Watch for common pests (spider mites, mealybugs).

description: Popular aroid with arrow-shaped leaves that change form as they mature, can trail or climb
commonExamples: Syngonium podophyllum (Arrowhead plant, Goosefoot plant, Nephthytis)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) ideal. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves change from arrow-shaped to lobed as they mature. Can trail or climb with support. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Cane-forming aroids with variegated foliage, toxic sap (handle with care)
commonExamples: Dieffenbachia seguine (Dumb cane), D. amoena (Giant dumb cane), D. 'Tropic Snow'
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light maintains variegation. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe large leaves monthly. Toxic sap causes mouth irritation - handle with care and wash hands after touching. Prune leggy stems to encourage bushiness.

description: Most common pothos variety with green and yellow variegated leaves, extremely easy-care
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of neglect and inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light maintains golden variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent for beginners. Toxic to pets.

description: Pothos variety with white and green marbled variegation, requires more light than golden pothos to maintain variegation
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Marble Queen' (Marble Queen pothos), E. aureum 'Snow Queen' (more white variegation)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent watering. Bright indirect light is essential to maintain white variegation - low light causes reversion to green. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. More light-demanding than golden pothos.

description: Swiss cheese vine with smaller, perforated leaves compared to Monstera deliciosa
commonExamples: Monstera adansonii (Monkey mask, Swiss cheese vine)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60-70%) encourages larger leaves with more fenestrations. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Provide moss pole or trellis for climbing - this encourages larger, more fenestrated leaves. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Can trail or climb.

description: Vibrant chartreuse pothos variety with solid bright green-yellow leaves, adds bright color to indoor spaces
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum 'Neon' (Neon pothos, Lime pothos), E. aureum 'Neon' variegated (with darker green variegation)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very easy-care like other pothos varieties. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant chartreuse color; low light causes darkening. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Adds bright color to indoor spaces. Toxic to pets.

description: Striking aroid with dark green leaves and white pinstripes, compact growth habit, variegation can revert to solid green
commonExamples: Philodendron 'Birkin' (Birkin philodendron), may show red variegation as it matures
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light maintains white pinstripes; low light may cause reversion to solid green. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Variegation can revert - prune reverted leaves. May show red variegation as it matures.

description: Classic trailing aroid with heart-shaped leaves, extremely easy-care and fast-growing
commonExamples: Philodendron hederaceum (Heart-leaf philodendron, Sweetheart plant), P. hederaceum 'Brasil' (variegated), P. hederaceum 'Lemon Lime'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing trailing plant. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent air purifier. Toxic to pets.

description: Velvety trailing aroid with heart-shaped leaves that shimmer in light, bronze-green with purple undersides
commonExamples: Philodendron hederaceum var. hederaceum (Philodendron micans, Velvet philodendron), can trail or climb with support
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly more moist than other philodendrons. Bright indirect light enhances velvety sheen and purple undersides. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Can trail or climb with support. Repot every 1-2 years. Velvety leaves are delicate - avoid touching. Toxic to pets.

description: Rare aroid with dark green and pink variegated leaves, requires bright light to maintain variegation, can revert to solid green
commonExamples: Philodendron erubescens 'Pink Princess' (PPP), P. erubescens 'White Princess' (white variegation), P. erubescens 'White Knight'
careTips: Water when top 1-2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Bright indirect light is essential to maintain pink variegation - low light causes reversion to solid green. High humidity (70%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Variegation is unstable - prune reverted leaves. Rare and expensive - handle with care. Toxic to pets.

description: Popular tropical aroid with distinctive split and perforated leaves (fenestrations), develops larger leaves with age
commonExamples: Monstera deliciosa (Swiss cheese plant, Split-leaf philodendron, Mexican breadfruit), M. adansonii (Monkey mask, Swiss cheese vine)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Bright indirect light encourages fenestrations (splits) in mature leaves. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Provide moss pole or trellis for climbing - this encourages much larger leaves with more fenestrations. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe large leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Vining aroids that trail or climb, easy-care houseplants with excellent air-purifying qualities
commonExamples: Epipremnum aureum (Pothos, Devil's ivy), Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos, Silver pothos), Philodendron hederaceum (Heart-leaf philodendron)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is slightly dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect to medium light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length and encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Excellent air purifiers. Easy-care houseplants perfect for beginners. Toxic to pets.

description: Tropical aroids with large arrow-shaped leaves (elephant ears), require high humidity and consistent moisture
commonExamples: Xanthosoma sagittifolium (Arrowleaf elephant ear), X. violaceum (Blue taro), X. 'Lime Zinger'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. High humidity (60-80%) essential - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Maintain warm temperatures (65-80°F). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Mist leaves daily or use humidifier. Repot annually in spring. Large arrow-shaped leaves. Some species go dormant in winter.

description: Epiphytic fern with wavy, strap-like fronds emerging from a central rosette, resembles a bird's nest
commonExamples: Asplenium nidus (Bird's nest fern), A. antiquum, A. 'Crispy Wave'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't pour water into the central rosette - water around the base. Repot every 2-3 years. Wavy, strap-like fronds.

description: Classic houseplant ferns in the Nephrolepis genus with feathery fronds, prefer high humidity and consistent moisture
commonExamples: Nephrolepis exaltata (Boston fern), N. cordifolia (Sword fern, Fishbone fern), N. exaltata 'Bostoniensis'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let fully dry. Mist daily or use humidifier to maintain 50-60% humidity. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced liquid fertilizer at half strength. Trim dead fronds at base with clean scissors. Repot every 1-2 years in spring when roots fill container. Excellent air purifiers. Brown tips indicate low humidity or inconsistent watering. Keep away from heating vents.

description: Compact fern with round, button-like leaflets on arching fronds, more tolerant of dry air than most ferns
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred - more tolerant than most ferns. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years. Compact growth habit. Round, button-like leaflets. More forgiving than delicate ferns.

description: Non-flowering vascular plants with delicate fronds, many species thrive in high humidity and indirect light
commonExamples: Nephrolepis exaltata (Boston fern), Adiantum (Maidenhair fern), Pteris (Ribbon fern), Asplenium (Bird's nest fern), Platycerium (Staghorn fern)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Most ferns prefer high humidity (60-80%) - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns delicate fronds. Mist leaves regularly or use humidifier. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 1-2 years in spring. Remove dead fronds at base. Many species are sensitive to chemicals in tap water - use filtered or distilled water. Research specific fern species for exact requirements.

description: Deciduous fern with silvery-gray fronds with purple accents, can be grown indoors in containers
commonExamples: Athyrium niponicum (Japanese painted fern), A. niponicum 'Pictum', A. 'Ghost'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred; some morning sun enhances coloration. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Goes dormant in winter - reduce watering. Repot every 2-3 years. Silvery-gray fronds with purple accents. Deciduous - fronds die back in winter.

description: Delicate ferns in the Adiantum genus with fan-shaped leaflets, requiring high humidity and consistent moisture
commonExamples: Adiantum raddianum (Delta maidenhair), A. capillus-veneris (Southern maidenhair), A. pedatum (Northern maidenhair)
careTips: Never let soil dry - keep constantly moist but not waterlogged. High humidity (70%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with diluted balanced fertilizer (quarter strength). Avoid touching delicate fronds. Repot carefully every 1-2 years in spring. Very challenging plant - requires consistent care.

description: Fern with fuzzy rhizomes that resemble rabbit's feet, trailing over the pot edge, more tolerant of dry conditions
commonExamples: Davallia fejeensis (Rabbit's foot fern, Lacy hare's foot fern), D. trichomanoides
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred - more tolerant than most ferns. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't bury the fuzzy rhizomes - let them trail over pot edge. Repot every 2-3 years. Unique fuzzy rhizomes resemble rabbit's feet.

description: Epiphytic fern with distinctive antler-like fronds, typically mounted on boards or grown in baskets
commonExamples: Platycerium bifurcatum (Staghorn fern, Elkhorn fern), P. grande (Giant staghorn), P. superbum
careTips: Mounted: Soak entire plant weekly for 15-30 minutes. Potted: Keep soil moist but not soggy. High humidity (60-70%) essential. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by soaking in diluted fertilizer solution. Mount on wood or grow in hanging basket. Shield fronds (brown base fronds) protect roots. Don't remove shield fronds. Unique antler-like appearance.

description: Feathery palm native to Madagascar with arching fronds, excellent air purifier
commonExamples: Dypsis lutescens (Areca palm, Butterfly palm, Golden cane palm, Yellow palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) beneficial. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly with damp cloth. Repot every 2-3 years when roots fill container. Excellent air purifier. Brown tips indicate low humidity or overwatering. Feathery arching fronds.

description: Hardy, slow-growing palm with fan-shaped leaves, very low-maintenance and cold-tolerant
commonExamples: Chamaerops humilis (European fan palm, Mediterranean fan palm, Dwarf fan palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Very slow-growing. Cold-tolerant compared to other palms. Repot every 3-4 years. Low-maintenance palm.

description: Elegant, slow-growing palm native to Lord Howe Island, very low-maintenance and tolerant of low light
commonExamples: Howea forsteriana (Kentia palm, Sentry palm, Thatch palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Low to bright indirect light tolerated - very adaptable. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and elegant. Very low-maintenance palm. Brown tips indicate overwatering or low humidity.

description: Slow-growing, clumping palm with fan-shaped leaves, very low-maintenance and tolerant of low light
commonExamples: Rhapis excelsa (Lady palm, Broadleaf lady palm), R. humilis (Slender lady palm)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Low to bright indirect light tolerated. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer at half strength. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and clumping habit. Very low-maintenance. Brown tips indicate overwatering.

description: Fast-growing palm with feathery fronds, requires high humidity and consistent moisture
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (water when top inch is dry). Never let fully dry out. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with palm fertilizer. Wipe fronds monthly. Repot annually in spring. Fast-growing but requires consistent care. Brown tips indicate low humidity or inconsistent watering.

description: Small, low-light tolerant palm native to Central America with delicate fronds, perfect for offices and low-light spaces
commonExamples: Chamaedorea elegans (Parlor palm, Neanthe bella palm, Good luck palm)
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Keep slightly moist but avoid overwatering. Low to bright indirect light tolerated - perfect for offices. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Slow-growing and compact. One of the best low-light palms. Brown tips indicate overwatering or low humidity.

description: Succulent in the Asparagaceae family with swollen caudex that stores water (not a true palm), very drought tolerant
commonExamples: Beaucarnea recurvata (Ponytail palm, Elephant's foot, Bottle palm)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Caudex (swollen base) stores water making it very drought tolerant. Overwatering causes root rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 3-5 years. Not a true palm despite the name. Can live for decades.

description: Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with rosette-forming leaves, some varieties are monocarpic
commonExamples: Aeonium arboreum (Tree houseleek), A. 'Zwartkop' (Black rose), A. haworthii (Pinwheel aeonium), A. 'Kiwi'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). More water-tolerant than some succulents but still drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Some varieties are monocarpic (die after flowering). Repot every 2-3 years. Rosette-forming succulents.

description: Medicinal succulent with gel-filled leaves, commonly used for skin care
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Remove offsets (pups) when 1/3 size of parent to propagate. Repot every 2-3 years. Gel from leaves has medicinal properties for skin care. Overwatering causes rot. Toxic to pets if ingested. Mildly toxic to humans if ingested; gel is safe for topical skin use.

description: Rosette-forming succulents in the Asphodelaceae family with medicinal properties, many produce offsets (pups) for propagation
commonExamples: Aloe vera (Medicinal aloe, Burn plant), A. arborescens (Torch aloe, Candelabra aloe), A. polyphylla (Spiral aloe), A. aristata (Lace aloe)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Remove offsets (pups) when they're 1/3 the size of parent plant to propagate. Repot every 2-3 years. Many species have medicinal properties.

description: Trailing succulent with delicate, plump blue-green leaves that drop easily if disturbed
commonExamples: Sedum morganianum (Burro's tail, Donkey's tail, Lamb's tail)
careTips: Water when soil is dry, but more frequently than most succulents. Handle very carefully - leaves drop easily if disturbed. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun may burn. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot carefully every 2-3 years. Very delicate - avoid moving once established.

description: Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with thick fleshy leaves, many form tree-like structures over time
commonExamples: Crassula ovata (Jade plant, Money tree), C. perforata (String of buttons), C. tetragona (Miniature pine tree), C. arborescens (Silver jade plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Reduce watering significantly in winter when growth slows. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Can be trained as bonsai. Repot every 2-3 years. Many form tree-like structures over time.

description: Rosette-forming succulents with colorful, often powdery leaves, popular in arrangements
commonExamples: Echeveria elegans, E. 'Perle von Nurnberg', E. agavoides, E. pulidonis
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves - water on leaves can cause rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Remove dead lower leaves. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular in succulent arrangements. Powdery coating (farina) protects from sun - don't rub off.

description: Diverse genus including many succulent species with milky sap (toxic, handle with care)
commonExamples: Euphorbia trigona (African milk tree), E. milii (Crown of thorns), E. obesa (Baseball plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-4 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Milky sap is toxic and can cause skin irritation - handle with care and wash hands after touching. Repot every 2-3 years. Diverse genus with many forms. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Tongue-shaped succulents related to Haworthia, shade-tolerant and easy-care
commonExamples: Gasteria bicolor, G. verrucosa, G. 'Little Warty'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More frequent than desert succulents. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; tolerates lower light than most succulents. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Shade-tolerant and easy-care. Related to Haworthia.

description: Succulents in the Crassulaceae family with rosette-forming leaves, often called ghost plants
commonExamples: Graptopetalum paraguayense (Ghost plant, Mother-of-pearl plant), G. 'Copper Rose', G. 'Purple Delight'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - more light enhances coloration. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 2-3 years. Rosette-forming with beautiful coloration. Often called ghost plants.

description: Small rosette succulents that tolerate lower light than most succulents, perfect for windowsills
commonExamples: Haworthia cooperi, H. fasciata (Zebra plant), H. attenuata, H. limifolia
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More frequent than desert succulents. Bright indirect to medium light preferred; tolerates lower light than most succulents. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Perfect for windowsills. Small rosette-forming succulents.

description: Classic succulent with thick, glossy green leaves, can live for decades and grow into a small tree
commonExamples: Crassula ovata (Jade plant, Money plant, Lucky plant)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - needs good light to maintain compact growth. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with balanced fertilizer at quarter strength. Can live for decades and grow into small tree. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years. Symbol of good luck. Overwatering causes root rot. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Stone-like succulents that mimic pebbles in their native habitat, have specific dormancy periods when they should not be watered
commonExamples: Lithops (Living stones, Pebble plants), various species with different colors and patterns
careTips: Water ONLY during growth periods (spring and fall) when new leaves appear. Keep completely dry during summer and winter dormancy - even minimal watering during dormancy causes rot. Very minimal watering even when active (every 2-4 weeks). Bright direct light essential. Low humidity preferred. Fertilize very sparingly during active growth only. Repot every 3-5 years in very well-draining soil. Stone-like appearance mimics pebbles. Very specific care requirements.

description: Large genus of succulents in the Crassulaceae family, includes both trailing and upright varieties
commonExamples: Sedum morganianum (Burro's tail), S. rubrotinctum (Jelly bean plant), S. adolphii (Golden sedum), S. 'Autumn Joy'
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Repot every 2-3 years. Many varieties available - trailing and upright. Very easy-care succulents.

description: Hardy succulents in the Crassulaceae family known as hen and chicks, form rosettes and produce offsets
commonExamples: Sempervivum tectorum (Common houseleek, Hen and chicks), S. arachnoideum (Cobweb houseleek), many cultivars
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize sparingly (2-3 times per year) with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Produces offsets (chicks) around parent plant (hen). Repot every 2-3 years. Very cold-hardy succulents.

description: Large genus of succulents in the Asteraceae family, includes trailing varieties like string of pearls (many reclassified to Curio)
commonExamples: Curio rowleyanus (syn. Senecio rowleyanus; String of pearls), Curio radicans (syn. S. radicans; String of bananas), Curio repens (syn. Senecio serpens; Blue chalk sticks), Curio talinoides subsp. mandraliscae (syn. Senecio mandraliscae)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with succulent fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Many are trailing plants. Repot every 2-3 years. Large genus with many varieties.

description: Trailing succulent with banana-shaped leaves, faster growing than String of Pearls
commonExamples: Curio radicans (String of bananas, syn. Senecio radicans)
careTips: Water when leaves show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Faster growing than String of Pearls. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Handle carefully to avoid leaf drop. Banana-shaped leaves. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Trailing succulent with leaves shaped like leaping dolphins
commonExamples: Curio × peregrinus (String of dolphins, syn. Senecio × peregrinus)
careTips: Water when leaves show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Unique dolphin-shaped leaves. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Handle carefully. Toxic if ingested by pets.

description: Trailing succulent with heart-shaped leaves and purple undersides, produces tubers along stems
commonExamples: Ceropegia woodii (String of hearts, Rosary vine, Chain of hearts)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than String of Pearls due to tubers along stems. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Produces tubers along stems for storage. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Heart-shaped leaves with purple undersides.

description: Trailing succulent with bead-like leaves, perfect for hanging baskets
commonExamples: Curio rowleyanus (String of pearls, syn. Senecio rowleyanus), C. herreianus (String of beads)
careTips: Water when pearls (leaves) show slight wrinkling - this indicates thirst. Avoid overwatering which causes rot. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Bead-like leaves are delicate - handle carefully. Very popular trailing succulent.

description: Trailing peperomia with small, patterned leaves resembling turtle shells, slower growing than other string plants
commonExamples: Peperomia prostrata (String of turtles, Turtle vine), P. prostrata 'Variegata' (variegated form)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep slightly more moist than other string plants but still avoid overwatering. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Slower growing than other string plants. Perfect for hanging baskets. Repot every 2-3 years. Small patterned leaves resembling turtle shells.

description: Drought-adapted plants with water-storing leaves, need excellent drainage
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 1-3 weeks depending on conditions). Water deeply but infrequently. Excellent drainage is essential - use cactus/succulent mix. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with succulent fertilizer at half strength. Repot every 2-3 years. Drought-adapted plants with water-storing leaves.

description: Round, barrel-shaped cacti that can grow quite large, very low-maintenance
commonExamples: Echinocactus grusonii (Golden barrel cactus), Ferocactus (Barrel cactus), E. texensis (Horse crippler)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Full sun to bright indirect light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Can grow quite large. Repot every 3-5 years. Very low-maintenance. Handle with care - sharp spines.

description: Desert plants in the Cactaceae family with spines and areoles, need excellent drainage and bright light
commonExamples: Echinocactus (Barrel cactus), Opuntia (Prickly pear, Bunny ears), Mammillaria (Pincushion cactus), Ferocactus
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-6 weeks). Water deeply but infrequently. Reduce significantly or stop watering in winter dormancy (November-February). Bright direct light essential - full sun preferred. Low humidity preferred. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Excellent drainage essential. Repot every 3-5 years. Handle with care - spines are sharp.

description: Forest cactus that blooms around Christmas, requires cool temperatures and reduced light to flower, has rounded leaf segments
commonExamples: Schlumbergera × buckleyi (Christmas cactus, True Christmas cactus), S. truncata (Thanksgiving cactus, often mislabeled as Christmas cactus)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in fall (September-October) to encourage blooms - this triggers bud formation. More frequent watering than desert cacti. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct hot sun. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cool temperatures (60-65°F) and reduced light in fall encourage flowering. Repot every 2-3 years. Rounded leaf segments distinguish from Thanksgiving cactus.

description: Forest cactus that blooms in spring, with rounded leaf segments
commonExamples: Hatiora gaertneri (Easter cactus, syn. Rhipsalidopsis gaertneri)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in winter (December-February) to encourage spring blooms. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Cool temperatures in winter encourage flowering. Repot every 2-3 years. Rounded leaf segments. Blooms in spring (Easter time).

description: Epiphytic cacti native to tropical forests, require different care from desert cacti with higher humidity needs
commonExamples: Schlumbergera (Christmas cactus, Thanksgiving cactus), Rhipsalis (Mistletoe cactus), Epiphyllum (Orchid cactus, Queen of the night)
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. More frequent watering than desert cacti. Reduce watering in fall for bloom induction. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Epiphytic cacti native to tropical forests. Repot every 2-3 years in well-draining mix. Different care from desert cacti.

description: Round, woolly cactus covered in white hairs, produces pink flowers
commonExamples: Mammillaria hahniana (Old lady cactus), M. bocasana (Powder puff cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Covered in white hairs giving woolly appearance. Produces pink flowers in spring. Repot every 3-5 years. Compact, round growth habit.

description: Flat-padded cacti in the Opuntia genus, can produce edible fruit, very low-maintenance
commonExamples: Opuntia ficus-indica (Indian fig opuntia), O. microdasys (Bunny ears), O. humifusa (Eastern prickly pear)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, less in winter). Very drought tolerant. Full sun to bright indirect light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Well-draining soil essential. Flat, pad-like stems. Can produce edible fruit. Repot every 3-5 years. Handle with extreme care - tiny glochids are very irritating.

description: Trailing cactus with long, thin stems covered in spines, produces bright pink or red flowers
commonExamples: Aporocactus flagelliformis (Rat tail cactus), Disocactus flagelliformis
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 2-3 weeks in summer, less in winter). More water-tolerant than some cacti. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with cactus fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit - perfect for hanging baskets. Produces bright pink or red flowers. Repot every 2-3 years. Long, thin trailing stems.

description: Small, round cactus with star-shaped pattern, very slow-growing and rare
commonExamples: Astrophytum asterias (Star cactus, Sand dollar cactus, Sea urchin cactus)
careTips: Water when soil is completely dry (every 3-4 weeks in summer, very little in winter). Very drought tolerant. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize sparingly (2-3 times per year) with cactus fertilizer at quarter strength. Well-draining soil essential. Very slow-growing. Star-shaped pattern on top. Produces yellow flowers. Repot every 3-5 years. Rare and protected in wild.

description: Forest cactus that blooms in late fall, similar to Christmas cactus but with pointed leaf segments
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist spring through summer. Reduce watering in fall (September-October) to encourage blooms. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pointed leaf segments distinguish from Christmas cactus. Blooms in late fall (Thanksgiving time). Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Bromeliads with pink flower spikes and silver-banded leaves
commonExamples: Aechmea fasciata (Silver vase plant, Urn plant), A. 'Blue Rain'
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Flower spike lasts months. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent plant dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Compact flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with fuzzy leaves and colorful blooms, avoid getting water on leaves. Includes various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers.
commonExamples: Saintpaulia ionantha (African violet), various cultivars with different flower colors, single, double, or ruffled flowers
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist. Always water from bottom or avoid wetting leaves - water on leaves causes permanent spots. Use room temperature water. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with African violet fertilizer to encourage continuous blooms. Repot annually in spring. Remove spent flowers. Crown rot is common - avoid overwatering.

description: Tropical plants in the Bromeliaceae family with rosette growth and central cups (tanks) that hold water
commonExamples: Guzmania (Flaming sword), Tillandsia (some species), Aechmea (Urn plant), Neoregelia (Blushing bromeliad)
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation and mosquito breeding. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated. Most bloom once then produce pups.

description: Tuberous flowering plants in the Primulaceae family with heart-shaped leaves and upswept flowers
commonExamples: Cyclamen persicum (Florist's cyclamen), C. hederifolium (Hardy cyclamen), various colors
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves and crown. Cool temperatures (60-65°F) extend bloom time. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (50%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Upswept, colorful flowers.

description: Fragrant flowering shrubs in the Rubiaceae family with glossy leaves and white blooms, require high humidity
commonExamples: Gardenia jasminoides (Cape jasmine, Common gardenia), G. 'August Beauty', G. 'Veitchii'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (water when top inch is dry). Acidic soil essential (pH 5.0-6.5). Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks spring through fall with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Very fragrant white flowers. Prune after flowering. Can be finicky - requires consistent care. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Tuberous flowering plants in the Gesneriaceae family with velvety leaves and large, bell-shaped flowers
commonExamples: Sinningia speciosa (Gloxinia, Florist's gloxinia), various colors and patterns
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. Water from bottom to avoid wetting leaves. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during flowering with high-phosphorus fertilizer. Goes dormant after flowering - reduce watering and allow foliage to die back. Repot when dormant. Large, bell-shaped velvety flowers. Velvety leaves.

description: Colorful bromeliads with bright, long-lasting flower spikes
careTips: Keep central cup (tank) filled with water at all times. Water soil when dry. Change cup water monthly to prevent stagnation. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall by adding diluted fertilizer to cup water. Bright, long-lasting flower spikes. After flowering, plant produces offsets (pups) - parent dies but pups can be separated and repotted.

description: Classic wax plant with thick, waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. carnosa 'Krimson Princess', H. carnosa 'Compacta'
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems (peduncles) - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Heart-shaped hoya often sold as single leaves, slow-growing but charming
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Very slow-growing - single leaves may never grow into full plant. If you have a stem cutting (not just leaf), it will grow. Repot every 2-3 years. Charming heart-shaped leaves.

description: Epiphytic vines in the Apocynaceae family with waxy leaves and fragrant star-shaped flowers, also called wax plants
commonExamples: Hoya carnosa (Wax plant, Porcelain flower), H. pubicalyx, H. kerrii (Sweetheart hoya, Valentine hoya)
careTips: Water when most of pot is dry (every 1-2 weeks). More drought tolerant than many houseplants. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun encourages flowering. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Don't remove spent flower stems - they rebloom. Repot every 2-3 years. Fragrant star-shaped flowers. Can trail or climb.

description: Fragrant flowering vines in the Oleaceae family, popular for their sweet-smelling blooms
commonExamples: Jasminum polyanthum (Pink jasmine), J. sambac (Arabian jasmine), J. officinale (Common jasmine)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (water when top inch is dry). Bright indirect to direct light preferred - more light encourages flowering. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Provide support for climbing. Prune after flowering. Very fragrant flowers. Can be grown as houseplant or outdoor in warm climates. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Flowering succulents in the Crassulaceae family with vibrant long-lasting blooms and fleshy leaves
commonExamples: Kalanchoe blossfeldiana (Flaming Katy, Florist kalanchoe), K. tomentosa (Panda plant, Chocolate soldier), Bryophyllum daigremontianum (Mother of thousands, syn. K. daigremontiana)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves which can cause rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. To rebloom, provide 12-14 hours of darkness daily for 6 weeks. Remove spent flowers. Repot every 1-2 years. Vibrant long-lasting blooms.

description: Aroids with white spathes and dark green foliage, excellent air purifiers, droop dramatically when thirsty as a watering indicator. Includes various cultivars ranging from compact to large.
commonExamples: Spathiphyllum wallisii (Peace lily), S. wallisii 'Domino', S. 'Sensation', S. floribundum, S. 'Mauna Loa'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy, water when leaves droop slightly. Fertilize every 6-8 weeks during growing season. Remove spent flowers to encourage new blooms. Repot when roots fill container, typically every 1-2 years. Toxic to humans and pets if ingested; causes mouth irritation.

description: Moth orchids, most common and beginner-friendly orchid genus in the Orchidaceae family with long-lasting blooms. Available in various colors.
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid, Phal), various hybrid cultivars in many colors
careTips: Soak roots weekly for 15-20 minutes, then allow to dry between waterings. Never let sit in water. Avoid getting water in crown (center) which causes fatal crown rot. Use well-draining orchid bark mix, never regular potting soil. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize weekly spring through fall with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Repot every 1-2 years when bark breaks down. Blooms last 2-3 months. Most beginner-friendly orchid.

description: Foliage begonias prized for colorful, patterned leaves in shades of silver, pink, red, and green. Includes stunning colorful and patterned varieties.
commonExamples: Begonia rex-cultorum, B. maculata (Polka dot begonia), B. 'Escargot', B. 'Iron Cross', various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry completely. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use pebble tray or humidifier. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant leaf colors; direct sun fades colors. Avoid wetting leaves which causes spots. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Water from bottom when possible. Repot every 1-2 years. Prone to powdery mildew - ensure good air circulation.

description: Flowering begonias grown from tubers, often with large showy blooms in various colors
commonExamples: Begonia × tuberhybrida (Tuberous begonia), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during active growth (spring through fall). Reduce watering significantly during dormancy period (winter) when leaves die back. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct hot sun. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks during active growth with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage blooms. Store tubers dry in winter. Repot tubers in spring. Large showy blooms in various colors.

description: Prayer plant with oval leaves featuring peacock-like patterns, leaves fold up at night
commonExamples: Goeppertia makoyana (Peacock plant, Cathedral windows), Calathea makoyana
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Repot every 1-2 years. Peacock-like pattern on leaves.

description: Popular prayer plant with dark green leaves and purple undersides, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night
commonExamples: Goeppertia roseopicta 'Medallion' (Calathea medallion), G. roseopicta 'Dottie' (darker variety), G. roseopicta 'Rosy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity.

description: Large prayer plant with silver-striped round leaves, requires high humidity, leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty)
commonExamples: Goeppertia orbifolia (Calathea orbifolia, Round-leaved calathea), one of the larger calathea varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun fades silver stripes. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. One of the larger calathea varieties. Wipe large leaves monthly.

description: Prayer plant with wavy, patterned leaves resembling a rattlesnake's tail
commonExamples: Goeppertia lancifolia (Calathea rattlesnake, syn. Calathea lancifolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wavy, patterned leaves resembling rattlesnake's tail. Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water and low humidity.

description: Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with patterned leaves that fold up at night, more tolerant than some prayer plants
commonExamples: Ctenanthe burle-marxii (Fishbone prayer plant), C. oppenheimiana (Giant bamburanta), C. 'Golden Mosaic'
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) preferred - more tolerant than some prayer plants. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Classic prayer plant with red-veined leaves that fold up at night
commonExamples: Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), M. leuconeura 'Erythroneura', M. leuconeura 'Kerchoveana'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Red-veined leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly.

description: Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with distinctive veining in various colors, will wilt dramatically when thirsty
commonExamples: Fittonia albivenis, F. verschaffeltii (Nerve plant, Mosaic plant), F. 'Pink Angel', F. 'Red Anne'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (70%+) essential - use humidifier or terrarium. Will wilt dramatically when thirsty but recovers quickly when watered. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for terrariums. Distinctive veining in various colors.

description: Plants in Marantaceae family with leaves that fold up at night (nyctinasty), require high humidity
commonExamples: Calathea (Goeppertia), Maranta leuconeura (Prayer plant), Stromanthe sanguinea
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, never let dry. High humidity (60-70%) essential - use humidifier. Use only distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning from minerals. Bright indirect light preferred; direct sun burns leaves. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (nyctinasty). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Sensitive to tap water, low humidity, and drafts.

description: Prayer plants in the Marantaceae family with colorful, patterned leaves that fold up at night
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy. High humidity (60%+) essential - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Use distilled or filtered water to prevent leaf browning. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Leaves fold up at night (prayer plant behavior). Colorful, patterned leaves. Repot every 1-2 years.

description: Classic trailing vine with lobed leaves, can be grown indoors or outdoors
commonExamples: Hedera helix (English ivy, Common ivy), H. helix 'Glacier', H. helix 'Needlepoint'
careTips: Keep soil slightly moist. Cooler temperatures (60-70°F) preferred. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prone to spider mites - mist regularly and inspect leaves. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing vine with grape-like leaves, easy-care houseplant
commonExamples: Cissus rhombifolia (Grape ivy, Oak leaf ivy), C. alata
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy-care houseplant. Grape-like leaves. Can trail or climb with support.

description: Variegated heart-leaf philodendron with green and yellow-chartreuse leaves, easy-care trailing plant
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains variegation; tolerates low light but may lose variegation. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Fast-growing trailing plant. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Green and yellow-chartreuse variegation. Toxic to pets.

description: Trailing aroids often called satin pothos, with silvery-splotched leaves, easy-care houseplants
commonExamples: Scindapsus pictus (Satin pothos, Silver pothos), S. pictus 'Argyraeus', S. pictus 'Exotica', S. treubii 'Moonlight'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Very forgiving of inconsistent care. Bright indirect light maintains silvery variegation; tolerates low light. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Trailing growth habit. Prune to control length. Repot every 1-2 years. Silvery-splotched leaves. Often called satin pothos but not a true pothos. Toxic to pets.

description: Fast-growing trailing plants in the Commelinaceae family with colorful striped or solid leaves
commonExamples: Tradescantia zebrina (Inch plant, Wandering Jew, Silver inch plant), T. fluminensis, T. pallida (Purple heart)
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist, allow to dry slightly between waterings. Very fast-growing - may need frequent pruning. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; low light causes leggy growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for hanging baskets. Easy to propagate from cuttings.

description: Fast-growing trailing plant with purple and silver striped leaves
commonExamples: Tradescantia zebrina (Inch plant, Wandering Jew, Silver inch plant)
careTips: Keep soil lightly moist, allow to dry slightly between waterings. Very fast-growing. Bright indirect light maintains purple and silver stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips to encourage bushiness. Repot every 1-2 years. Perfect for hanging baskets. Easy to propagate from cuttings.

description: Fast-growing grasses in the Poaceae family, can be clumping or running types, popular for screening and containers
commonExamples: Bambusa (Clumping bamboo), Phyllostachys (Running bamboo), Fargesia (Cold-hardy clumping bamboo), indoor varieties like Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Running types spread aggressively - contain with barriers or plant in containers. Clumping types are more manageable. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with high-nitrogen fertilizer. Prune to control height and remove old canes. Container-grown bamboo needs regular repotting. Research clumping vs running types before planting. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Indoor lucky bamboo grows in water or soil.

description: Large tropical plants in the Strelitziaceae family with distinctive bird-like flowers and banana-like leaves
commonExamples: Strelitzia reginae (Bird of paradise, Crane flower), S. nicolai (Giant white bird of paradise, Wild banana)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist in growing season, reduce in winter. Bright indirect to direct light preferred - needs lots of light to flower. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Distinctive bird-like flowers. Can grow quite large - provide adequate space. Toxic to pets.

description: Miniature trees created through cultivation techniques - care varies by species, this is a general guide
careTips: Water when soil surface is dry - check daily as small pots dry quickly. Avoid both over and under-watering. Adjust based on species needs - research your specific tree type. Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with bonsai fertilizer. Prune regularly to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years with bonsai soil mix. Requires patience and consistent care. Each species has specific requirements.

description: Popular Pilea with round, coin-like leaves on upright stems
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light preferred; rotate regularly for even growth. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Produces offsets (pups) that can be separated and repotted. Repot every 1-2 years. Round, coin-like leaves on upright stems. Popular and easy-care.

description: Colorful foliage plants in the Lamiaceae family with vibrant leaves in various patterns and colors, pinch flowers to maintain foliage
commonExamples: Plectranthus scutellarioides (Coleus, Painted nettle), various hybrid cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors; direct sun may fade colors. High humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch flower spikes immediately to encourage leaf growth - flowers signal end of plant's life. Pinch tips regularly to maintain bushy growth. Repot annually. Easy to propagate from cuttings. Annual in most climates.

description: Colorful tropical foliage plants in the Euphorbiaceae family with vibrant leaves in red, orange, yellow, and green, sensitive to changes
commonExamples: Codiaeum variegatum (Croton, Garden croton), C. variegatum 'Petra', C. variegatum 'Mammy'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier. Bright indirect to direct light essential to maintain vibrant colors. Sensitive to changes - avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. May drop leaves if stressed (drafts, temperature changes, low humidity). Repot every 1-2 years. Wipe leaves monthly. Toxic to pets.

description: Ancient palm-like plants in the Cycadaceae family, slow-growing with stiff fronds, many are endangered in the wild
commonExamples: Cycas revoluta (Sago palm, King sago), Zamia (Coontie, Cardboard palm), Dioon (Dioon cycad), Macrozamia
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry slightly between waterings - avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Low to medium humidity is fine. Fertilize 2-3 times per year during growing season with palm fertilizer. Very slow-growing - repot every 3-5 years. Remove dead fronds at base. Toxic to pets if ingested. Ancient plants that have existed for millions of years. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Popular but finicky ficus with large violin-shaped leaves, requires consistent care and stable environment
commonExamples: Ficus lyrata (Fiddle-leaf fig, FLF), F. lyrata 'Bambino' (compact variety), F. lyrata variegated (rare)
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Very sensitive to overwatering and location changes - may drop leaves. Avoid drafts and sudden temperature changes. Bright indirect light essential - rotate regularly for even growth. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular but finicky - requires consistent care and stable environment. Toxic to pets.

description: Bright golden conifer with lemony scent, popular as indoor or patio plant, requires good air circulation
commonExamples: Cupressus macrocarpa 'Goldcrest' (Lemon cypress, Goldcrest cypress, Monterey cypress 'Goldcrest')
careTips: Keep soil moist but not waterlogged. Excellent drainage essential. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Good air circulation essential - avoid stagnant air. Medium humidity (40-50%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to maintain shape. Repot every 2-3 years. Bright golden color with lemony scent. Popular as indoor or patio plant.

description: Dracaena species often grown in water or soil, popular for feng shui, not a true bamboo
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo, Chinese water bamboo, Ribbon plant), can be grown in water or soil
careTips: In water: Change water weekly, keep water level consistent. In soil: Water when top inch is dry. Bright indirect light preferred; avoid direct sun. Medium humidity is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength (if in soil) or add to water monthly. Can be grown in water indefinitely or in soil. Popular for feng shui arrangements. Not a true bamboo. Repot every 2-3 years if in soil.

description: Popular houseplant in the Malvaceae family with palmate leaves, often sold with braided trunk, symbol of good luck
commonExamples: Pachira aquatica (Money tree, Guiana chestnut, Malabar chestnut)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot - very sensitive to soggy soil. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Often sold with braided trunk - don't untie. Repot every 2-3 years. Symbol of good luck. Palmate leaves. Remove yellowing leaves.

description: Indoor conifer native to Norfolk Island, popular as holiday plant, not a true pine but resembles one, sensitive to dry air. Requires consistent moisture.
commonExamples: Araucaria heterophylla (Norfolk Island pine, Star pine)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid drying out completely. High humidity (50-60%) preferred - mist regularly in dry conditions or use humidifier. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Sensitive to dry air - brown needles indicate low humidity. Repot every 2-3 years. Popular as holiday plant. Not a true pine despite the name.

description: Plants in the Oxalidaceae family with clover-like leaves that fold at night, some species go dormant seasonally
commonExamples: Oxalis triangularis (Purple shamrock, False shamrock), O. regnellii (Green shamrock, Lucky clover)
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth. Reduce significantly or stop watering during dormancy when leaves die back - this is normal. Bright indirect to direct light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly during active growth with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Clover-like leaves fold at night. Some species go dormant seasonally - don't discard, it will regrow. Repot every 2-3 years. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Piperaceae family with thick, succulent-like leaves
commonExamples: Peperomia obtusifolia (Baby rubber plant), P. caperata (Emerald ripple), P. argyreia (Watermelon peperomia)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants due to succulent-like leaves. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplants. Thick, succulent-like leaves store water.

description: Trailing peperomia with small, round succulent-like leaves, perfect for hanging baskets
commonExamples: Peperomia 'Hope' (P. deppeana × P. quadrifolia, Hope peperomia), trailing variety with round leaves
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Perfect for hanging baskets. Trailing growth habit. Small, round succulent-like leaves. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Compact peperomia with dark green tops and red undersides, star-shaped growth, textured leaves
commonExamples: Peperomia caperata 'Rosso' (Peperomia Rosso), P. caperata 'Emerald Ripple' (green variety), P. caperata 'Luna Red'
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. More drought tolerant than many tropical plants. Bright indirect light enhances red undersides. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Star-shaped growth habit. Textured leaves with dark green tops and red undersides. Repot every 2-3 years.

description: Compact peperomia with silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind
commonExamples: Peperomia argyreia (Watermelon peperomia, syn. P. sandersii)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Bright indirect light maintains silver stripes. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Silver-striped leaves resembling watermelon rind. Compact growth habit. Repot every 2-3 years. Easy-care houseplant.

description: Compact tropical foliage plants in the Urticaceae family with round or textured leaves
commonExamples: Pilea peperomioides (Chinese money plant, Pancake plant, UFO plant), P. cadierei (Aluminum plant), P. involucrata (Friendship plant)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Allow to dry between waterings. Avoid overwatering. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Compact growth habit. Round or textured leaves. Repot every 1-2 years. Easy to propagate from offsets or cuttings.

description: Colorful foliage plants in the Acanthaceae family with spotted leaves in pink, red, or white, pinch to maintain bushy growth
commonExamples: Hypoestes phyllostachya (Polka dot plant, Freckle face), various color cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, avoid letting dry out. High humidity (60%+) preferred - use humidifier or pebble tray. Bright indirect light maintains vibrant colors. Fertilize every 2 weeks spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Pinch tips regularly to encourage branching and maintain bushy growth. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong plant life. Repot annually. Annual in most climates. Easy to propagate from cuttings.

description: Popular ficus with large, glossy dark green or burgundy leaves, can grow into a tree
commonExamples: Ficus elastica (Rubber plant, Rubber tree), F. elastica 'Burgundy'
careTips: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil is dry. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Sensitive to location changes - may drop leaves when moved. Bright indirect light preferred; some direct morning sun is fine. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Wipe large glossy leaves monthly. Prune to control height. Repot every 2-3 years. Can grow into a tree. Toxic to pets.

description: Popular houseplant in the Araliaceae family with palmately compound leaves radiating from central point
commonExamples: Schefflera actinophylla (Umbrella tree, Octopus tree), S. arboricola (Dwarf umbrella tree, Hawaiian elf)
careTips: Water when top 2 inches of soil is dry. Keep consistently moist but not soggy. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium to high humidity (50-60%) preferred.
