Fertilize monthly spring through fall with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Prune to control size and encourage bushiness. Wipe leaves monthly. Repot every 2-3 years. Palmately compound leaves radiating from central point. Can grow quite large. Toxic to pets.

description: Deciduous trees in the Betulaceae family with distinctive white or colored bark, prefer cool climates and moist soil
commonExamples: Betula papyrifera (Paper birch), B. nigra (River birch), B. pendula (Silver birch, European white birch), B. alleghaniensis (Yellow birch)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist, especially during hot weather. Prefer cool climates and moist, well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late summer to avoid bleeding sap. Mulch around base to keep roots cool and moist. Distinctive white or colored bark. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Rutaceae family with fragrant flowers and edible fruits, require warm climates or indoor protection
commonExamples: Citrus limon (Lemon), C. sinensis (Orange, Sweet orange), C. × aurantifolia (Lime), C. reticulata (Mandarin, Tangerine)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly in growing season). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus-specific fertilizer. Prune after fruiting to maintain shape. Protect from frost - bring indoors or cover if temperatures drop below 32°F. Fragrant flowers precede fruit. Require warm climates or indoor protection in winter. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Cone-bearing evergreen trees and shrubs, include pines, spruces, firs, and cedars, provide year-round structure
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar), Juniperus (Juniper)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun preferred for most species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many species are drought-tolerant once established. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements and mature size. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Trees that lose their leaves seasonally, provide shade in summer and allow light in winter
commonExamples: Acer (Maple, Sugar maple, Red maple), Quercus (Oak, Red oak, White oak), Betula (Birch), Fraxinus (Ash), Ulmus (Elm)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly for first 2-3 years). Water well during establishment period. Mature trees are more drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during dry spells. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer, allow light in winter. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Trees adapted to arid desert conditions, extremely drought tolerant once established
commonExamples: Prosopis (Mesquite, Honey mesquite), Acacia (Acacia, Sweet acacia), Parkinsonia (Palo verde, Blue palo verde), Olneya (Ironwood)
careTips: Minimal watering once established (monthly or less). Deep but infrequent watering during establishment (first 1-2 years). Allow to dry completely between waterings. Full sun essential. Well-draining soil critical. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Prune in late winter. Extremely drought tolerant once established. Adapted to arid desert conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous trees and shrubs in the Cornaceae family with showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage
commonExamples: Cornus florida (Flowering dogwood), C. kousa (Kousa dogwood, Japanese dogwood), C. nuttallii (Pacific dogwood), C. mas (Cornelian cherry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering and fruit development. Prefer partial shade to full sun depending on climate. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Showy spring flowers and colorful fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Trees that retain foliage year-round, provide year-round structure and privacy screening
commonExamples: Pinus (Pine, Eastern white pine, Scots pine), Picea (Spruce, Norway spruce, Blue spruce), Abies (Fir, Balsam fir), Cedrus (Cedar)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation. Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Provide year-round structure and privacy screening. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees grown for edible fruits, require proper pruning and often need cross-pollination
commonExamples: Malus domestica (Apple), Prunus persica (Peach), Pyrus (Pear), Prunus avium (Cherry)
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape and encourage fruiting. Many require cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties nearby. Thin fruit for larger, healthier fruits. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Ancient deciduous trees in the Ginkgoaceae family, living fossil, popular street tree in China, male and female trees
commonExamples: Ginkgo biloba (Ginkgo, Maidenhair tree), male cultivars (no fruit), 'Autumn Gold', 'Princeton Sentry'
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment. Mature trees are drought tolerant. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring during establishment. Prune in late winter. Ancient living fossil. Popular street tree in China. Plant male cultivars to avoid smelly fruit. Beautiful golden fall foliage. Very long-lived. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Deciduous and evergreen trees in the Magnoliaceae family with large, fragrant flowers, many species are ancient flowering plants
commonExamples: Magnolia grandiflora (Southern magnolia), M. × soulangeana (Saucer magnolia), M. stellata (Star magnolia), M. liliiflora (Lily magnolia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering. Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Large, fragrant flowers. Many species are ancient flowering plants. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Deciduous trees in the Sapindaceae family known for brilliant fall foliage, many species are popular landscape trees
commonExamples: Acer saccharum (Sugar maple), A. rubrum (Red maple), A. palmatum (Japanese maple), A. platanoides (Norway maple), A. saccharinum (Silver maple)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Mature trees are more drought tolerant. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during establishment. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base. Brilliant fall foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Majestic deciduous and evergreen trees in the Fagaceae family, provide shade and wildlife habitat, many species are long-lived
commonExamples: Quercus rubra (Red oak), Q. alba (White oak), Q. virginiana (Live oak), Q. palustris (Pin oak), Q. robur (English oak)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during establishment (first 2-3 years). Mature trees are drought tolerant but benefit from deep watering during extended dry periods. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in early spring with tree fertilizer during first 5 years. Prune in late winter when dormant. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Provide shade in summer. Many species live for centuries. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Flowering shrubs in the Ericaceae family, part of the Rhododendron genus, prefer acidic soil and partial shade
commonExamples: Rhododendron (Azalea), R. indicum (Southern Indian azalea), R. kiusianum (Kyushu azalea), evergreen and deciduous varieties, Kurume and Southern Indica hybrids
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Acidic soil essential (pH 4.5-6.0) - use acidifying fertilizer and mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering. Mulch to keep roots cool and retain moisture. Don't plant too deep - keep root ball slightly above soil level. Research evergreen vs deciduous varieties for your climate. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Buxaceae family with dense foliage, popular for hedges and topiary, slow-growing and long-lived
commonExamples: Buxus sempervirens (Common boxwood, English boxwood), B. microphylla (Littleleaf boxwood), B. sinica (Korean boxwood)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during establishment. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late spring or early summer to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Dense foliage perfect for hedges and topiary. Slow-growing and long-lived. Watch for boxwood blight and pests. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Theaceae family with beautiful flowers, includes tea plant, popular in Chinese gardens
commonExamples: Camellia japonica (Japanese camellia), C. sinensis (Tea plant), C. sasanqua (Sasanqua camellia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained, acidic soil essential. Partial shade preferred - avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering. Beautiful flowers in winter/spring. Tea plant (C. sinensis) leaves are used for tea. Popular in Chinese gardens. Protect from harsh winds. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen plants that tolerate cold winter temperatures, provide year-round structure and color in landscapes
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood), Ilex (Holly, American holly, English holly), Taxus (Yew), Juniperus (Juniper), Thuja (Arborvitae)
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent winter desiccation (brown needles). Mulch around base to retain moisture and protect roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Tolerate cold winter temperatures. Provide year-round structure and color. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Woody shrubs that retain foliage year-round, provide structure and privacy in landscapes
commonExamples: Buxus (Boxwood, American boxwood), Ligustrum (Privet), Ilex (Holly, American holly), Taxus (Yew), Camellia
careTips: Deep soak regularly (weekly during growing season). Keep consistently moist during establishment (first 1-2 years). Water well before ground freezes in winter to prevent desiccation. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with shrub fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape. Mulch around base. Provide structure and privacy year-round. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Woody shrubs grown primarily for their flowers, many require specific soil pH for optimal bloom color
commonExamples: Hydrangea (Bigleaf, Panicle, Oakleaf), Rhododendron (Azalea), Syringa (Lilac), Forsythia
careTips: Deep soak at base regularly (weekly during growing season). Keep consistently moist during flowering period. Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with flowering shrub fertilizer. Many require specific soil pH for optimal bloom color (e.g., hydrangeas - acidic for blue, alkaline for pink). Prune after flowering or in late winter depending on species. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Oleaceae family with bright yellow early spring flowers before leaves appear
commonExamples: Forsythia × intermedia (Border forsythia), F. suspensa (Weeping forsythia), F. viridissima (Greenstem forsythia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering to maintain shape and encourage next year's blooms. Remove old canes to rejuvenate. Bright yellow early spring flowers. Very cold hardy. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Popular flowering shrubs in the Hydrangeaceae family, flower color depends on soil pH for some varieties
commonExamples: Hydrangea macrophylla (Bigleaf hydrangea, Mophead, Lacecap), H. paniculata (Panicle hydrangea), H. arborescens (Smooth hydrangea), H. quercifolia (Oakleaf hydrangea)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Mulch to retain moisture. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Bigleaf hydrangeas: acidic soil (pH 5.5) produces blue flowers; alkaline soil (pH 6.5+) produces pink flowers. Prune after flowering or in late winter depending on species. Research specific type for pruning requirements - some bloom on old wood, others on new wood. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen coniferous shrubs and trees in the Cupressaceae family, drought-tolerant and versatile for landscapes
commonExamples: Juniperus horizontalis (Creeping juniper, Blue rug juniper), J. chinensis (Chinese juniper), J. virginiana (Eastern red cedar), J. scopulorum (Rocky Mountain juniper)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring with evergreen fertilizer. Prune in late winter or early spring. Many varieties available from groundcovers to trees. Very versatile for landscapes. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Aromatic flowering herbs in the Lamiaceae family with silvery foliage and fragrant purple flowers, drought-tolerant once established
commonExamples: Lavandula angustifolia (English lavender), L. stoechas (Spanish lavender), L. × intermedia (Lavandin)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-draining soil essential - avoid heavy clay. Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Drought-tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Harvest flowers when buds are just opening. Silvery foliage and fragrant purple flowers. Excellent for dry gardens. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Oleaceae family with fragrant spring flowers in shades of purple, pink, white, and blue
commonExamples: Syringa vulgaris (Common lilac, French lilac), S. × persica (Persian lilac), S. reticulata (Japanese tree lilac)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, slightly alkaline soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering to remove spent blooms and shape. Remove old canes to rejuvenate. Fragrant spring flowers. Very cold hardy. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen shrubs in the Oleaceae family with highly fragrant flowers, popular in Chinese gardens and tea
commonExamples: Osmanthus fragrans (Sweet osmanthus, Fragrant olive, Tea olive), O. × fortunei, various cultivars
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Highly fragrant flowers in fall. Popular in Chinese gardens and tea. Can be grown in containers. Evergreen foliage. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen and deciduous flowering shrubs in the Ericaceae family, prefer acidic soil and partial shade, many are large-growing
commonExamples: Rhododendron (Rhododendron), R. catawbiense (Catawba rhododendron), R. maximum (Rosebay rhododendron), R. yakushimanum (Yakushima rhododendron), large-leaved and small-leaved varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Acidic soil essential (pH 4.5-6.0) - use acidifying fertilizer and mulch with pine needles or oak leaves. Partial shade preferred - morning sun with afternoon shade is ideal. Protect from hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Prune immediately after flowering if needed. Mulch to keep roots cool and retain moisture. Don't plant too deep. Research specific variety for mature size - some grow very large. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Aromatic evergreen herbs in the Lamiaceae family, drought-tolerant once established, can grow as shrub or groundcover
commonExamples: Rosmarinus officinalis (Rosemary), upright and prostrate varieties, R. officinalis 'Arp' (cold-hardy), R. officinalis 'Tuscan Blue'
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Avoid overwatering which causes root rot. Well-draining soil essential. Very drought tolerant once established. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Prune regularly to harvest and maintain shape. Can grow as shrub or groundcover depending on variety. Aromatic evergreen herb. Excellent for Mediterranean gardens. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Classic flowering shrubs in the Rosaceae family with fragrant blooms, require good air circulation
commonExamples: Rosa (Rose), various types: Hybrid tea, Floribunda, Grandiflora, Climbing roses
careTips: Regular deep watering at base (2-3 times per week during growing season). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease (black spot, powdery mildew). Mulch around base to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly spring through fall with rose fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Good air circulation essential to prevent disease. Research specific type for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous and evergreen shrubs in the Adoxaceae family with showy flowers, colorful berries, and fall foliage
commonExamples: Viburnum opulus (European cranberrybush, Snowball viburnum), V. dentatum (Arrowwood), V. plicatum (Japanese snowball), V. carlesii (Koreanspice viburnum)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering and fruiting. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering if needed. Mulch around base. Showy flowers, colorful berries, and fall foliage. Many species attract birds. Research specific species for exact requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Fall-blooming perennial flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, provide late-season color with daisy-like flowers
commonExamples: Symphyotrichum (Aster, New England aster), S. novae-angliae (New England aster), S. novi-belgii (New York aster), Callistephus (China aster, annual)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Pinch back in early summer to encourage bushier growth and more flowers. Divide every 2-3 years in spring. Stake tall varieties. Remove spent flowers to encourage more blooms. Excellent for fall color. Attract butterflies and pollinators. Research perennial vs annual varieties. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Herbaceous perennials in the Asteraceae family with bright yellow daisy-like flowers and dark centers, native wildflowers
commonExamples: Rudbeckia hirta (Black-eyed Susan, Gloriosa daisy), R. fulgida (Orange coneflower), R. laciniata (Cutleaf coneflower), R. triloba (Brown-eyed Susan)
careTips: Water deeply once per week during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Self-seeds readily. Divide every 3-4 years. Bright yellow daisy-like flowers. Native wildflowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Fall-blooming perennial flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, provide late-season color, many varieties available
commonExamples: Chrysanthemum × morifolium (Garden mum, Florist's chrysanthemum), C. indicum, cushion, daisy, pompon, and spider varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and again in midsummer with balanced fertilizer. Pinch back until mid-July to encourage bushiness and more flowers. Divide every 2-3 years in spring. Stake tall varieties. Excellent for fall color. Many are treated as annuals but are perennials in zones 5-9. Research hardiness for your zone. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Herbaceous perennials in the Asteraceae family with daisy-like flowers and prominent central cones, attract butterflies and birds
commonExamples: Echinacea purpurea (Purple coneflower), E. pallida (Pale purple coneflower), E. angustifolia (Narrow-leaved coneflower), E. tennesseensis (Tennessee coneflower)
careTips: Water deeply once per week during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for best flowering. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Leave seed heads in fall for birds. Divide every 3-4 years. Attract butterflies and birds. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Daisy-like flowering plants in the Asteraceae family, include both annual and perennial types with white or colored petals
commonExamples: Leucanthemum vulgare (Oxeye daisy), L. × superbum (Shasta daisy), Gerbera (Gerbera daisy), Bellis perennis (English daisy), Argyranthemum (Marguerite daisy)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize monthly during growing season with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Divide perennials every 2-3 years in spring or fall. Cut back after flowering. Many are excellent cut flowers. Attract butterflies and pollinators. Research specific type (annual vs perennial) for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Hardy perennial flowering plants in the Asphodelaceae family, each flower lasts one day but plants produce many blooms
commonExamples: Hemerocallis (Daylily), H. fulva (Orange daylily, Tawny daylily), H. 'Stella de Oro', reblooming and evergreen varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water deeply during flowering period. Full sun to partial shade - more sun equals more flowers. Fertilize in early spring and after first bloom with balanced fertilizer. Divide every 3-5 years in spring or fall to maintain vigor. Remove spent flowers daily. Cut back foliage in fall or spring. Very low-maintenance and drought-tolerant once established. Research reblooming varieties for extended flowering. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Non-woody perennial flowers that die back in winter and regrow from roots in spring, provide long-term garden structure
commonExamples: Hemerocallis (Daylily), Hosta (Plantain lily), Echinacea (Coneflower), Rudbeckia (Black-eyed Susan), Salvia (Sage)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering during growing season). Deep watering encourages strong root systems. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Cut back dead foliage in late fall or early spring. Divide every 3-5 years to maintain vigor. Provide long-term garden structure. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Shade-loving perennial foliage plants in the Asparagaceae family, grown for their attractive leaves in various colors and sizes
commonExamples: Hosta (Plantain lily, Funkia), H. 'Francee', H. 'Patriot', H. 'Blue Angel', H. 'Sum and Substance', miniature and giant varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Mulch to retain moisture and keep roots cool. Partial to full shade preferred - morning sun is fine but avoid hot afternoon sun. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Divide every 3-5 years in spring or fall. Remove flower stalks after blooming to focus energy on foliage (unless you enjoy the flowers). Watch for slugs and snails which love hostas. Excellent for shade gardens. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial flowering plants in the Iridaceae family with distinctive sword-like leaves and showy flowers, include bearded and beardless types
commonExamples: Iris germanica (Bearded iris), I. sibirica (Siberian iris), I. ensata (Japanese iris), I. reticulata (Dwarf iris), I. pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry slightly after flowering. Many prefer well-drained soil. Full sun essential for best flowering (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Divide bearded irises every 3-4 years in late summer. Plant rhizomes with top exposed to sun. Remove spent flowers. Cut back foliage in fall. Research specific type (bearded, beardless, bulbous) for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Herbaceous and tree perennials in the Paeoniaceae family with large, fragrant flowers in spring, long-lived garden favorites
commonExamples: Paeonia lactiflora (Garden peony, Chinese peony), P. suffruticosa (Tree peony), P. officinalis (Common peony), P. tenuifolia (Fernleaf peony)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Plant with eyes (buds) 2 inches below soil surface. Support heavy blooms with stakes. Cut back foliage in fall. Long-lived - can thrive for decades. Large, fragrant flowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Herbaceous perennials and annuals in the Lamiaceae family with spikes of colorful flowers, many are drought-tolerant
commonExamples: Salvia officinalis (Common sage, Garden sage), S. nemorosa (Woodland sage), S. farinacea (Mealycup sage), S. splendens (Scarlet sage)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 1-2 weeks). Drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage reblooming. Cut back in late fall or early spring. Many species are drought-tolerant. Spikes of colorful flowers. Attract hummingbirds and butterflies. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Herbaceous perennials in the Crassulaceae family with succulent leaves and clusters of star-shaped flowers, drought-tolerant groundcovers
commonExamples: Sedum 'Autumn Joy' (Autumn joy stonecrop), S. spectabile (Showy stonecrop), S. telephium (Orpine), S. spurium (Two-row stonecrop)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 2-3 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Deadhead spent flowers or leave for winter interest. Cut back in late winter. Drought-tolerant groundcovers. Clusters of star-shaped flowers. Attract butterflies. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial plants adapted to woodland and shade conditions, often prefer rich organic soil
commonExamples: Hosta (Plantain lily), Astilbe (False spirea), Helleborus (Lenten rose, Hellebore), Dicentra (Bleeding heart), Pulmonaria (Lungwort)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly watering). Many prefer consistent moisture but well-drained soil. Avoid waterlogged conditions. Partial to full shade preferred. Rich organic soil preferred - amend with compost. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Mulch to retain moisture. Deadhead spent flowers. Divide every 3-5 years. Adapted to woodland conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Annual and perennial flowers in the Begoniaceae family with colorful blooms and attractive foliage, shade-tolerant
commonExamples: Begonia × semperflorens-cultorum (Wax begonia), B. × tuberhybrida (Tuberous begonia), B. boliviensis (Bolivian begonia), B. rex (Rex begonia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil essential. Partial shade to full shade preferred - avoid direct sun. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers. Mulch to retain moisture. Colorful blooms and attractive foliage. Shade-tolerant. Research specific type for exact requirements. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Annual flowers that prefer cooler temperatures, often planted in fall or early spring for winter/spring blooms
commonExamples: Viola × wittrockiana (Pansy), Violas (Viola, Johnny-jump-up), Calendula (Pot marigold), Primula (Primrose), Dianthus (Sweet William)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers and leaves. Consistent moisture important during flowering period. Partial sun to full sun depending on species. Prefer cooler temperatures (60-70°F) - plant in fall or early spring. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Mulch to retain moisture. Annual - replant each season.

description: Annual flowers in the Asteraceae family with delicate, daisy-like blooms in shades of pink, white, and purple, easy to grow
commonExamples: Cosmos bipinnatus (Garden cosmos, Mexican aster), C. sulphureus (Yellow cosmos, Orange cosmos), C. atrosanguineus (Chocolate cosmos)
careTips: Water regularly but allow to dry between waterings (2-3 times per week). Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize sparingly - too much fertilizer reduces blooms. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Self-seeds readily. Delicate, daisy-like blooms. Attract butterflies and bees. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Popular annual and perennial flowering plants, include zonal geraniums (Pelargonium) and true geraniums (hardy geraniums)
commonExamples: Pelargonium × hortorum (Zonal geranium), P. peltatum (Ivy geranium), Geranium (Hardy geranium, Cranesbill), scented-leaf varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained (2-3 times per week). Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Full sun preferred for best flowering. Fertilize every 2 weeks with high-phosphorus fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Zonal geraniums are annuals in most climates; hardy geraniums are perennials. Research type (annual Pelargonium vs perennial Geranium) for exact requirements. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Shade-loving annual flowering plants in the Balsaminaceae family with colorful blooms, excellent for shady areas
commonExamples: Impatiens walleriana (Busy Lizzie, Garden impatiens), I. balsamina (Garden balsam), I. hawkeri (New Guinea impatiens), double-flowered varieties
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 times per week). Don't allow to dry out - wilting damages plants. Partial to full shade preferred - avoid hot afternoon sun. Bright indirect light is ideal. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent for shady gardens and containers. Plant after last frost. Watch for downy mildew - choose resistant varieties if this is a problem in your area. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Hardy annual flowering plants in the Asteraceae family with bright yellow, orange, or red flowers, excellent for pest control
commonExamples: Tagetes (Marigold), T. patula (French marigold), T. erecta (African marigold), T. tenuifolia (Signet marigold), Calendula (Pot marigold)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Allow to dry slightly between waterings. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead regularly to encourage continuous blooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent companion plants - repel nematodes and some pests. Easy to grow from seed. Plant after last frost. Research variety type for size and bloom characteristics. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Annual and perennial flowers in the Tropaeolaceae family with edible flowers and leaves, trailing or climbing habit
commonExamples: Tropaeolum majus (Garden nasturtium, Indian cress), T. minus (Dwarf nasturtium), T. peregrinum (Canary creeper)
careTips: Water regularly but allow to dry between waterings (2-3 times per week). Prefer slightly dry conditions - too much water reduces flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize sparingly - rich soil reduces blooms. Edible flowers and leaves with peppery flavor. Trailing or climbing habit. Attract beneficial insects. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Popular annual flowering plants in the Solanaceae family with trumpet-shaped flowers, excellent for containers and hanging baskets
commonExamples: Petunia × hybrida (Garden petunia), grandiflora, multiflora, milliflora, and spreading/trailing varieties, P. integrifolia (Wild petunia)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 2 weeks with high-phosphorus fertilizer to encourage flowering. Deadhead regularly or shear back by one-third mid-season to encourage reblooming. Pinch back when young to encourage bushiness. Excellent for containers, hanging baskets, and borders. Plant after last frost. Research variety type for growth habit (upright vs trailing). Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Annual and perennial flowers in the Asteraceae family with large, cheerful yellow blooms that follow the sun
commonExamples: Helianthus annuus (Common sunflower), H. debilis (Beach sunflower), H. maximiliani (Maximilian sunflower), dwarf varieties
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake tall varieties. Deadhead to encourage side blooms or leave for birds. Large, cheerful yellow blooms. Attract birds and bees. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Annual flowers that thrive in summer heat, provide continuous blooms throughout warm season
commonExamples: Petunia (Petunia), Tagetes (Marigold, French marigold, African marigold), Zinnia (Zinnia), Impatiens (Busy Lizzie, prefer partial shade), Portulaca (Moss rose)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed in hot weather). Water at base to avoid wetting flowers which can cause disease. Consistent moisture prevents wilting. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Thrive in summer heat. Fertilize every 2 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Mulch to retain moisture. Annual - replant each season. Provide continuous blooms throughout warm season.

description: Annual flowers in the Asteraceae family with bright, daisy-like blooms in many colors, easy to grow from seed
commonExamples: Zinnia elegans (Common zinnia, Youth-and-old-age), Z. angustifolia (Narrowleaf zinnia), Z. haageana (Mexican zinnia), Z. peruviana (Peruvian zinnia)
careTips: Water at base regularly (2-3 times per week). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent powdery mildew. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Deadhead spent flowers to encourage continuous blooms. Easy to grow from seed. Bright, daisy-like blooms in many colors. Attract butterflies. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Climbing perennials in the Ranunculaceae family with large, showy flowers, require support and specific pruning
commonExamples: Clematis × jackmanii (Jackman clematis), C. terniflora (Sweet autumn clematis), C. montana (Anemone clematis), C. viticella (Italian clematis)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist, especially during flowering. Prefer cool roots and sunny tops - mulch around base. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune according to type - some bloom on new growth, others on old wood. Provide support for climbing. Large, showy flowers. Research specific type for exact pruning requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Plants that climb using tendrils, twining stems, or aerial roots, require support structures like trellises or fences
commonExamples: Jasminum (Jasmine, Star jasmine), Clematis (Clematis, Old man's beard), Lonicera (Honeysuckle), Wisteria, Parthenocissus (Virginia creeper)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around base to retain moisture especially for root zones. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Provide support structures (trellises, fences, arbors) for climbing. Fertilize monthly during growing season. Prune according to species - some bloom on new growth, others on old wood. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Climbing and shrubby plants in the Caprifoliaceae family with fragrant, tubular flowers, some species can be invasive
commonExamples: Lonicera japonica (Japanese honeysuckle), L. sempervirens (Trumpet honeysuckle, Coral honeysuckle), L. periclymenum (European honeysuckle), L. × brownii (Brown's honeysuckle)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune after flowering to control growth. Provide support for climbing varieties. Fragrant, tubular flowers. Attract hummingbirds. Some species can be invasive - check local regulations. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen climbing and groundcover plants in the Araliaceae family, can be invasive, excellent for covering walls and ground
commonExamples: Hedera helix (English ivy), H. hibernica (Atlantic ivy), Parthenocissus quinquefolia (Virginia creeper), P. tricuspidata (Boston ivy)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment (first year), then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to full shade depending on species. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control growth - can be invasive. Excellent for covering walls and ground. Evergreen foliage. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Fast-growing annual and perennial vines in the Convolvulaceae family with trumpet-shaped flowers that open in morning
commonExamples: Ipomoea purpurea (Common morning glory), I. tricolor (Heavenly blue morning glory), I. alba (Moonflower), I. quamoclit (Cypress vine)
careTips: Water regularly (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist during flowering. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Provide support for climbing. Deadhead to prevent self-seeding if desired. Fast-growing vines. Trumpet-shaped flowers open in morning. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Annual; grown for one season; no winter watering needed.

description: Vigorous climbing vines in the Fabaceae family with cascading clusters of fragrant flowers, require strong support
commonExamples: Wisteria sinensis (Chinese wisteria), W. floribunda (Japanese wisteria), W. frutescens (American wisteria), W. macrostachya (Kentucky wisteria)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential for flowering. Fertilize sparingly in spring - too much nitrogen reduces blooms. Prune twice yearly - summer and winter. Requires strong support - can damage structures. Cascading clusters of fragrant flowers. Very vigorous - can be invasive. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Low-growing perennial groundcover in the Polemoniaceae family with masses of spring flowers, excellent for rock gardens
commonExamples: Phlox subulata (Moss phlox, Creeping phlox, Moss pink), P. stolonifera (Creeping phlox)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Shear after flowering to maintain shape. Excellent for rock gardens and slopes. Masses of spring flowers. Forms dense mats. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Ornamental grasses in the Poaceae family, add texture and movement to landscapes, many are drought tolerant
commonExamples: Pennisetum (Fountain grass), Miscanthus (Maiden grass, Silver grass), Festuca (Fescue), Panicum (Switchgrass), Calamagrostis (Feather reed grass)
careTips: Occasional deep watering (every 2-3 weeks once established). Most are drought tolerant once established. Water regularly during establishment period (first year). Full sun preferred for most species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Cut back in late winter/early spring before new growth. Divide every 3-5 years to maintain vigor. Add texture and movement to landscapes. Research specific species for exact requirements. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Low-growing plants that spread to cover ground, useful for erosion control and reducing maintenance
commonExamples: Thymus (Thyme, Creeping thyme), Vinca (Periwinkle), Ajuga (Bugleweed), Pachysandra (Japanese spurge), Sedum (Stonecrop)
careTips: Light watering once established (every 1-2 weeks). Keep moist during establishment period (first 3-6 months). Most are drought tolerant after rooting. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Prune to control spread if needed. Useful for erosion control and reducing maintenance. Mulch between plants during establishment. Research specific species for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Grass species maintained as lawns, require regular mowing and maintenance for healthy growth
commonExamples: Cynodon dactylon (Bermuda grass), Festuca (Fescue, Tall fescue), Lolium (Ryegrass, Perennial ryegrass), Poa (Kentucky bluegrass), Zoysia (Zoysia grass)
careTips: Frequent deep watering (1-1.5 inches per week, 2-3 times per week). Water early morning (before 10am) to reduce evaporation and prevent disease. Avoid shallow frequent watering which encourages shallow roots. Full sun to partial shade depending on grass type. Fertilize 3-4 times per year with lawn fertilizer. Mow regularly at appropriate height for grass type. Aerate annually. Overseed in fall for cool-season grasses. Research specific grass type for exact requirements. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen groundcover in the Buxaceae family with glossy leaves, excellent for shady areas and erosion control
commonExamples: Pachysandra terminalis (Japanese spurge, Japanese pachysandra), P. procumbens (Allegheny spurge, Mountain pachysandra)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment (first year), then reduce to weekly. Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Partial to full shade preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control spread if needed. Excellent for shady areas. Glossy evergreen leaves. Spreads by rhizomes. Excellent for erosion control. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen groundcover in the Apocynaceae family with glossy leaves and spring flowers, can be invasive
commonExamples: Vinca minor (Common periwinkle, Lesser periwinkle), V. major (Bigleaf periwinkle, Greater periwinkle)
careTips: Water regularly during establishment, then reduce to weekly. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Partial shade to full shade preferred. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to control spread if needed. Glossy evergreen leaves. Spring flowers. Spreads by runners. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Fast-growing leafy green in the Brassicaceae family with peppery flavor, also known as rocket or roquette
commonExamples: Eruca sativa (Arugula, Rocket, Roquette), E. vesicaria (Wild arugula), Diplotaxis tenuifolia (Perennial wall rocket)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves when young for best flavor. Fast-growing. Peppery flavor. Can bolt in heat - provide shade in summer. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy green vegetable in the Brassicaceae family, also known as pak choi or Chinese cabbage, fast-growing
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. chinensis (Bok choy, Pak choi, Chinese cabbage), 'Shanghai', 'Joi Choi', 'Mei Qing Choi'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest whole heads or individual leaves. Fast-growing. Can bolt in heat - provide shade in summer. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cruciferous vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, harvest central head and side shoots, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. italica (Broccoli), 'Calabrese', 'Green Goliath', 'Waltham 29', 'Purple Sprouting'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest central head when tight and before flowers open. Side shoots will continue to produce. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cruciferous vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, produce small cabbage-like sprouts along stem, flavor improves after frost
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. gemmifera (Brussels sprouts), 'Long Island Improved', 'Jade Cross', 'Red Rubine'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Remove lower leaves as plant grows. Harvest sprouts from bottom up when 1-2 inches in diameter. Flavor improves after frost. Long growing season (90-100 days). Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, form tight heads, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. capitata (Cabbage), green, red, savoy varieties, 'Golden Acre', 'Red Express'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head formation. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest when heads are firm and reach desired size. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Can be stored for months. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cruciferous vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, form white, purple, or orange heads, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. botrytis (Cauliflower), white, purple, orange, and green (Romanesco) varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Blanch white varieties by tying leaves over head. Harvest when head is tight and before it separates. Prefer cool weather - very sensitive to heat. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Stalk vegetables in the Apiaceae family, require consistent moisture and rich soil, challenging to grow
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist (daily watering may be needed). Never allow to dry out. Rich, organic soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Blanch stalks by wrapping or hilling soil around base. Harvest outer stalks first. Challenging to grow - requires consistent care. Prefer cool weather. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy green vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, also known as Chinese flowering cabbage, popular in Chinese cuisine
commonExamples: Brassica rapa var. parachinensis (Choy sum, Chinese flowering cabbage, Cai xin)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest whole plant or individual leaves. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Popular in Chinese cuisine. Fast-growing. Can bolt in heat. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy green vegetable in the Brassicaceae family, cold-hardy and can overwinter in mild climates
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. viridis (Collard greens, Collards), 'Georgia', 'Vates', 'Champion'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Cold-hardy - flavor improves after frost. Can overwinter in mild climates. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Chinese broccoli in the Brassicaceae family with thick stems and small flower heads, essential in Chinese cuisine
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. alboglabra (Gai lan, Chinese broccoli, Kai-lan, Chinese kale)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest when flower buds are just forming. Both stems and leaves are edible. Prefer cool weather. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cold-hardy leafy green in the Brassicaceae family, flavor improves after frost, can overwinter in mild climates
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. acephala (Kale), curly kale, Lacinato (Dinosaur kale, Tuscan kale), Red Russian kale
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and keep leaves clean. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Flavor improves after frost. Can overwinter in mild climates. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Unique vegetables in the Brassicaceae family with swollen stem base, both bulb and leaves are edible, fast-growing
commonExamples: Brassica oleracea var. gongylodes (Kohlrabi), green and purple varieties, 'Early White Vienna', 'Purple Vienna'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for tender bulbs. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when bulb is 2-3 inches in diameter for best flavor. Both bulb and leaves are edible. Fast-growing (45-60 days). Prefer cool weather. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing leafy greens in the Asteraceae family, prefer cooler temperatures and can bolt (flower) in heat
commonExamples: Lactuca sativa (Lettuce), butterhead, romaine, leaf lettuce, and crisphead varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed in hot weather). Consistent moisture prevents bitterness and bolting (premature flowering). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves which can cause disease. Partial shade in hot climates helps prevent bolting. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly or cut whole head. Fast-growing - ready in 45-60 days. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring and fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy green vegetables in the Brassicaceae family with peppery flavor, fast-growing and cold-hardy
commonExamples: Brassica juncea (Mustard greens, Mustard spinach, Indian mustard), 'Southern Giant Curled', 'Red Giant', 'Tendergreen'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly. Fast-growing. Peppery flavor. Cold-hardy. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Chinese cabbage in the Brassicaceae family with elongated, barrel-shaped heads, essential in Chinese cuisine
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. pekinensis (Napa cabbage, Chinese cabbage, Wombok, Pe-tsai), 'Michihili', 'Blues', 'Rubicon'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for head formation. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Harvest when heads are firm. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can bolt in heat. Watch for cabbage worms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cool-season leafy green in the Amaranthaceae family, bolts quickly in heat, best grown in spring and fall
commonExamples: Spinacia oleracea (Spinach), smooth-leaf and savoy (crinkled) varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering may be needed). Consistent moisture prevents bolting (premature flowering) and ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Partial shade in warm climates. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly or cut whole plant. Bolts quickly in heat - best grown in spring and fall. Ready in 40-50 days. Watch for leaf miners. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Leafy green vegetable in the Amaranthaceae family with colorful stems, can be harvested continuously throughout season
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris subsp. cicla (Swiss chard, Rainbow chard, Rhubarb chard), 'Bright Lights', 'Fordhook Giant', 'Ruby Red'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture ensures tender leaves. Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Mulch around plants. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Colorful stems in red, yellow, orange, and white. Can harvest continuously throughout season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Small red beans in the Fabaceae family, very popular in Chinese and Japanese cuisine, used in desserts
commonExamples: Vigna angularis (Adzuki bean, Azuki bean, Red bean)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Fast-growing (90-120 days). Harvest when pods are dry and brown. Very popular in Chinese and Japanese cuisine. Used in desserts and sweet red bean paste. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing legume vegetables in the Fabaceae family, pole beans need support while bush beans are self-supporting
commonExamples: Phaseolus vulgaris (Green beans, Snap beans, String beans), pole and bush varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly - beans fix their own nitrogen. Pole beans need trellis or support; bush beans are self-supporting. Harvest regularly to encourage continued production. Fast-growing - ready in 50-60 days. Watch for bean beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Sweet peppers in the Solanaceae family with blocky, thick-walled fruits, most popular pepper variety
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Bell pepper, Sweet pepper), green, red, yellow, orange, purple varieties
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants if needed. Harvest when fruits reach desired size and color - green peppers are immature, colored peppers are fully ripe. Warm-season crop. Watch for aphids and pepper maggots. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Popular winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family with sweet, nutty flavor, excellent for storage
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when fully mature and rind is hard. Cure in warm place for 2 weeks before storage. Excellent for storage - can last 3-6 months. Sweet, nutty flavor. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Cucurbitaceae family, also known as muskmelon, requires long growing season
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space. Harvest when stem separates easily from fruit and fruit has sweet aroma. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Watch for aphids and cucumber beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Tall grain crop in the Poaceae family, requires pollination from wind or manual assistance, plant in blocks for better pollination
commonExamples: Zea mays (Corn, Maize), sweet corn, popcorn, and ornamental varieties
careTips: Regular deep watering (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist especially during tasseling and ear development - critical for kernel development. Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Plant in blocks (at least 4 rows) for better wind pollination. Fertilize when 12 inches tall and again when tassels appear. Tall plants - provide space. Ready in 60-100 days depending on variety. Watch for corn earworms. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Vining fruiting vegetables in the Cucurbitaceae family, need consistent moisture and support for climbing types
commonExamples: Cucumis sativus (Cucumber), slicing and pickling varieties, bush and vining types
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (daily watering in hot weather). Water at base to avoid leaf diseases like powdery mildew. Consistent moisture prevents bitter fruit. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Provide trellis or support for vining types. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest regularly when fruits are young and tender. Ready in 50-70 days. Watch for cucumber beetles and powdery mildew. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Young soybeans harvested green in the Fabaceae family, popular snack and vegetable, fast-growing
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Harvest when pods are plump and green but before they yellow. Fast-growing (75-90 days). Popular snack and vegetable. Boil or steam pods. Warm-season crop. Very popular in Asian cuisine. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Solanaceae family, also known as aubergine, requires long growing season
commonExamples: Solanum melongena (Eggplant, Aubergine), 'Black Beauty', 'Japanese Long', 'Italian', 'Rosa Bianca'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants if needed. Harvest when skin is glossy and firm. Warm-season crop - start indoors in cool climates. Requires long growing season. Watch for flea beetles and aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing legumes in the Fabaceae family, include bush and pole varieties, very popular vegetable
commonExamples: Phaseolus vulgaris (Green bean, Snap bean, String bean), bush and pole varieties, 'Blue Lake', 'Kentucky Wonder', 'Provider'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Support pole varieties with trellis. Harvest when pods are young and tender (before seeds bulge). Fast-growing (50-60 days). Continuous harvest encourages more production. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Very hot peppers in the Solanaceae family, among the hottest common peppers, use with extreme caution
commonExamples: Capsicum chinense (Habanero), 'Orange Habanero', 'Red Habanero', 'Chocolate Habanero', 'Caribbean Red'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when fully colored (orange, red, or chocolate). Extremely hot - use gloves when handling. Warm-season crop - requires long, hot season. Very hot peppers - use with extreme caution. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Medium-hot peppers in the Solanaceae family, popular for salsas and cooking, can be mild to moderately hot
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Jalapeño), 'Early Jalapeño', 'Jalapeño M', 'Mucho Nacho', 'Jalapeño Gigante'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when green for milder flavor, or when red for hotter flavor. Can be dried or smoked to make chipotle. Warm-season crop. Heat level varies by growing conditions. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing legumes in the Fabaceae family, very popular in Chinese cuisine, can be sprouted
commonExamples: Vigna radiata (Mung bean, Green gram), can be grown for beans or sprouts
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Fast-growing (60-90 days). Can be harvested as green pods or dried beans. Very popular in Chinese cuisine. Can be sprouted for bean sprouts. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Malvaceae family with edible pods, also known as lady's finger, heat-loving
commonExamples: Abelmoschus esculentus (Okra, Lady's finger, Gumbo), 'Clemson Spineless', 'Annie Oakley', 'Red Burgundy'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest pods when 2-4 inches long - daily harvesting encourages more production. Warm-season crop - very heat-loving. Tall plants may need staking. Watch for aphids and stink bugs. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Cool-season legume vegetables in the Fabaceae family, prefer cooler temperatures and need support for climbing varieties
commonExamples: Pisum sativum (Garden pea, English pea), shelling, snap, and snow pea varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base. Consistent moisture important during flowering and pod development. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in early spring or fall. Provide trellis or support for climbing varieties. Fertilize sparingly - peas fix their own nitrogen. Harvest regularly when pods are plump. Ready in 60-70 days. Watch for aphids. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetables in the Solanaceae family, need consistent moisture and warm temperatures
commonExamples: Capsicum annuum (Bell pepper, Chili pepper, Sweet pepper), various heat levels from sweet to very hot
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist but well-drained. Avoid water stress which causes blossom drop. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Warm temperatures required (70-85°F). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Stake plants to support heavy fruit. Harvest when fruits reach desired size and color. Ready in 60-90 days. Watch for aphids and pepper maggots. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large winter squash in the Cucurbitaceae family, popular for Halloween decorations and cooking, require long growing season
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Pumpkin), C. maxima (Giant pumpkin), 'Jack O'Lantern', 'Sugar Pie', 'Cinderella', 'Atlantic Giant'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Vining plants require space (10+ feet). Harvest when fully mature and rind is hard. Cure in warm place for 2 weeks before storage. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Perfect for Halloween decorations. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Edible-podded peas in the Fabaceae family, entire pod is eaten, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Pisum sativum var. macrocarpon (Snap pea, Sugar snap pea), 'Sugar Snap', 'Super Sugar Snap', 'Sugar Ann'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or fall. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Support with trellis. Harvest when pods are plump but before they become tough. Entire pod is eaten. Fast-growing (60-70 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Flat-podded peas in the Fabaceae family, entire pod is eaten, popular in Asian cuisine
commonExamples: Pisum sativum var. saccharatum (Snow pea, Chinese pea, Mangetout), 'Oregon Sugar Pod', 'Dwarf Gray Sugar'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or fall. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Support with trellis. Harvest when pods are flat and before seeds develop. Entire pod is eaten. Popular in Asian cuisine. Fast-growing (60-70 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Essential legumes in the Fabaceae family, used for tofu, soy sauce, and many products, important crop
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer (legumes fix nitrogen). Harvest when pods are plump and green (edamame) or when dry (mature beans). Essential crop. Used for tofu, soy sauce, and many products. Warm-season crop. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large fruiting vegetables in the Cucurbitaceae family, vining types need support or space to spread
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Zucchini, Summer squash, Yellow squash), C. maxima (Winter squash, Pumpkin), C. moschata (Butternut squash)
careTips: Regular deep watering at base (2-3 times per week). Keep consistently moist especially during fruit development. Avoid wetting leaves to prevent powdery mildew. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Vining types need support or space to spread (10+ feet). Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest summer squash when small and tender; winter squash when fully mature. Watch for squash bugs and powdery mildew. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetables in the Solanaceae family, require consistent moisture and support for vining types
commonExamples: Solanum lycopersicum (Tomato), determinate and indeterminate varieties
careTips: Deep, regular watering at base (2-3 times per week, daily in hot weather). Avoid wetting leaves to prevent disease (early blight, late blight). Consistent moisture prevents blossom end rot (calcium deficiency). Full sun essential (8+ hours daily). Stake or cage indeterminate varieties. Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with tomato fertilizer. Mulch to retain moisture. Harvest when fully colored. Ready in 60-90 days. Watch for tomato hornworms and diseases. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season fruiting vegetable in the Cucurbitaceae family, large vining plants require space and long growing season
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week, increase during fruit development. Consistent moisture critical during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Large vining plants require space. Harvest when tendril near stem turns brown and bottom sounds hollow when tapped. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Watch for aphids and cucumber beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Summer squash in the Cucurbitaceae family, fast-growing and prolific, harvest when small for best flavor
commonExamples: Cucurbita pepo (Zucchini, Summer squash, Courgette), 'Black Beauty', 'Golden', 'Cocozelle', 'Ronde de Nice'
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week. Consistent moisture important during fruiting. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when 6-8 inches long for best flavor - daily harvesting encourages more production. Fast-growing and prolific. Male and female flowers. Watch for squash bugs and vine borers. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Amaranthaceae family, both roots and greens are edible, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Beta vulgaris subsp. vulgaris (Beet, Garden beet, Red beet), 'Detroit Dark Red', 'Golden', 'Chioggia', 'Cylindra'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 3-4 inches apart. Harvest roots when 2-3 inches in diameter. Both roots and greens are edible. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Apiaceae family, require deep, loose soil free of rocks for straight roots
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting. Water deeply to encourage long roots. Deep, loose, rock-free soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer - too much nitrogen causes forked roots. Thin seedlings to 2-3 inches apart. Harvest when roots reach desired size. Can be left in ground in mild climates. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Large white radishes in the Brassicaceae family, popular in Asian cuisine, fast-growing
commonExamples: Raphanus sativus var. longipinnatus (Daikon, White radish, Mooli, Chinese radish), 'April Cross', 'Minowase'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents pithy roots. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 4-6 inches apart. Harvest when roots are 6-12 inches long. Fast-growing (50-70 days). Popular in Asian cuisine. Can be stored for weeks. Prefer cool weather. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Bulb vegetables in the Apiaceae family with licorice flavor, both bulb and fronds are edible
commonExamples: Foeniculum vulgare var. azoricum (Florence fennel, Finocchio), 'Zefa Fino', 'Orion'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture important for bulb development. Well-drained, fertile soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest when bulb is 3-4 inches in diameter. Both bulb and fronds are edible. Licorice flavor. Can bolt in heat - plant in spring or fall. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Bulb vegetables in the Amaryllidaceae family, reduce watering as bulbs mature to prevent rot
commonExamples: Allium cepa (Onion, Shallot), A. sativum (Garlic), A. fistulosum (Scallion, Green onion)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth (2-3 times per week). Reduce watering significantly as tops begin to yellow and bulbs mature - this allows bulbs to cure and prevents rot. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer until bulbs form. Plant garlic in fall for summer harvest; onions in spring. Harvest when tops fall over. Cure bulbs in dry, airy location. Toxic to pets. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Apiaceae family, flavor improves after frost, require long growing season
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting. Deep, loose, rock-free soil essential. Full sun preferred. Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 3-4 inches apart. Harvest after first frost for best flavor - can be left in ground over winter. Flavor improves after frost. Requires long growing season (100-120 days). Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Underground tuber vegetables in the Solanaceae family, require hilling (mounding soil) around stems as they grow
commonExamples: Solanum tuberosum (Potato), early, mid-season, and late varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents hollow heart and ensures uniform tuber development. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily).
