Hill (mound soil) around stems as they grow to protect developing tubers from sunlight (which causes greening). Fertilize at planting and when hilling. Harvest when plants die back. Store in cool, dark place. Ready in 70-120 days depending on variety. Watch for potato beetles. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Fast-growing root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, prefer cool weather and can be planted multiple times per season
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents pithy roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 1-2 inches apart. Harvest when roots reach size (20-60 days depending on variety). Fast-growing. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Can be planted multiple times per season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Vegetables grown for their edible underground parts, require loose well-drained soil for proper root development
commonExamples: Daucus carota (Carrot), Beta vulgaris (Beet, Sugar beet), Raphanus (Radish), Pastinaca sativa (Parsnip)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents splitting and ensures uniform growth. Loose, well-drained soil essential - avoid heavy clay. Full sun preferred. Thin seedlings to proper spacing for root development. Fertilize sparingly - too much nitrogen causes leafy growth at expense of roots. Harvest when roots reach desired size. Ready in 30-120 days depending on variety. Research specific vegetable for exact requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, cross between turnip and cabbage, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Brassica napus subsp. rapifera (Rutabaga, Swede, Neep), 'American Purple Top', 'Laurentian'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 6-8 inches apart. Harvest when roots are 3-5 inches in diameter. Prefer cool weather - plant in early spring or late summer. Flavor improves after frost. Can be stored for months. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Warm-season root vegetables in the Convolvulaceae family, also commonly called yams, require long growing season
careTips: Water deeply 2-3 times per week during growing season. Consistent moisture important during root development. Mulch around plants. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize with low-nitrogen fertilizer. Plant slips (rooted cuttings) after soil warms. Vining plants require space. Harvest before first frost when leaves start to yellow. Cure in warm, humid place for 2 weeks. Warm-season crop - requires long growing season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Root vegetables in the Brassicaceae family, both roots and greens are edible, prefer cool weather
commonExamples: Brassica rapa subsp. rapa (Turnip, White turnip), 'Purple Top White Globe', 'Tokyo Cross', 'Hakurei', 'Golden Ball'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents woody roots. Water at base. Well-drained, loose soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize with balanced fertilizer. Thin seedlings to 4-6 inches apart. Harvest roots when 2-3 inches in diameter. Both roots and greens are edible. Prefer cool weather - plant in spring or fall. Flavor improves after frost. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family, require cross-pollination for most varieties, need winter chill
commonExamples: Malus domestica (Apple), 'Gala', 'Fuji', 'Granny Smith', 'Honeycrisp', 'McIntosh', dwarf and standard sizes
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring to maintain shape and encourage fruiting. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ compatible varieties nearby. Thin fruit for larger, healthier apples. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when easily twists off branch. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with velvety skin, early bloomers susceptible to frost
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Early bloomers - very susceptible to late frosts. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Requires winter chill but blooms early. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Lauraceae family, require warm climates, popular for guacamole and salads
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil essential - avoid waterlogged conditions. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and summer with avocado fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Most varieties need cross-pollination. Harvest when mature (varies by variety). Require warm climates - protect from frost. Can be grown in containers in cooler climates. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial cane fruits in the Rosaceae family, produce fruit on second-year canes, can be trailing or erect varieties
commonExamples: Rubus fruticosus (Blackberry), trailing and erect varieties, thornless and thorny types
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit. Mulch around plants to retain moisture. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune fruited canes after harvest in summer. Support trailing varieties with trellis. Harvest when fully black and easily detaches. Can spread aggressively - contain with barriers. Replace plants every 8-10 years. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Acidic soil-loving berry shrubs in the Ericaceae family, require pH 4.5-5.5 and often need cross-pollination
commonExamples: Vaccinium corymbosum (Highbush blueberry), V. angustifolium (Lowbush blueberry), V. ashei (Rabbiteye blueberry)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Use acidic water if needed to maintain soil pH. Mulch with pine needles, pine bark, or sawdust to maintain acidity and moisture. Soil pH 4.5-5.5 essential - test and amend annually. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ compatible varieties. Prune in late winter. Harvest when fully blue. Research specific variety for exact requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family, sweet and sour varieties, require winter chill and often need cross-pollination
commonExamples: Prunus avium (Sweet cherry), P. cerasus (Sour cherry, Tart cherry), 'Bing', 'Rainier', 'Montmorency', 'Stella'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties nearby. Protect from birds with netting. Harvest when fully colored. Sweet cherries are more challenging than sour cherries. Research specific variety for exact requirements. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Low-growing evergreen shrubs in the Ericaceae family, require acidic soil and constant moisture, popular for Thanksgiving
commonExamples: Vaccinium macrocarpon (American cranberry), V. oxycoccos (Small cranberry)
careTips: Keep soil constantly moist - never allow to dry out. Acidic soil (pH 4.0-5.5) essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring with acid-loving plant fertilizer. Mulch with pine needles or peat moss. Can be grown in boggy conditions. Harvest in fall when berries are fully red. Popular for Thanksgiving. Very challenging to grow outside native bog conditions. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Cactus fruits in the Cactaceae family, also known as pitaya, popular tropical fruit with striking appearance
commonExamples: Hylocereus undatus (White-fleshed dragon fruit), H. costaricensis (Red-fleshed), Selenicereus (Yellow dragon fruit)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently (every 1-2 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with cactus fertilizer. Provide support for climbing habit. Self-fertile but cross-pollination improves yield. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Require warm climates. Popular tropical fruit. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Adoxaceae family with clusters of dark berries, popular for health benefits and jellies
commonExamples: Sambucus canadensis (American elderberry), S. nigra (European elderberry), 'Adams', 'York', 'Nova'
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter to remove old canes. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant 2+ varieties. Harvest clusters when fully ripe (dark purple/black). Berries must be cooked before eating. Popular for health benefits and jellies. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Moraceae family, can be grown in containers, some varieties produce two crops
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter. Self-fertile. Some varieties produce two crops (breba and main crop). Can be grown in containers. Harvest when soft and drooping. Protect from cold in winter if needed. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Deciduous shrubs in the Solanaceae family, also known as wolfberry, popular superfood, drought-tolerant
commonExamples: Lycium barbarum (Goji berry, Wolfberry), L. chinense (Chinese wolfberry)
careTips: Water deeply but infrequently once established (every 1-2 weeks). Very drought tolerant. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune in late winter to maintain shape. Self-fertile. Harvest berries when fully red. Popular superfood. Can be grown in containers. Very popular in China. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Perennial climbing vines in the Vitaceae family, produce clusters of berries, require pruning and support structures
commonExamples: Vitis vinifera (Wine grape), V. labrusca (American grape), V. rotundifolia (Muscadine), table and wine varieties
careTips: Deep watering weekly during growing season. Consistent moisture important during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune heavily in late winter - grapes fruit on new growth from previous year's wood. Provide strong support (trellis, arbor). Harvest when fully ripe and sweet. Many varieties need winter chill. Research specific variety for exact pruning requirements. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rhamnaceae family, also known as Chinese date or red date, drought-tolerant
commonExamples: Ziziphus jujuba (Jujube, Chinese date, Red date), 'Li', 'Lang', 'Sugar Cane'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Self-fertile but better with cross-pollination. Harvest when fully red and slightly wrinkled. Can be eaten fresh or dried. Very popular in China. Drought tolerant. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Small citrus trees in the Rutaceae family, entire fruit is edible including peel, cold-hardier than most citrus
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun essential. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully orange. Entire fruit is edible including peel. Cold-hardier than most citrus - can tolerate light frosts. Can be grown in containers. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Sapindaceae family, related to lychee, require tropical or subtropical climate
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, slightly acidic soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring and summer with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when skin is brown and fruit is sweet. Require tropical or subtropical climate. Related to lychee. Popular in Chinese cuisine. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with sweet, tangy fruits, popular in China and Japan
commonExamples: Eriobotrya japonica (Loquat, Japanese plum, Chinese plum), 'Champagne', 'Gold Nugget'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize in spring and summer with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain size and shape. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully yellow-orange and slightly soft. Can tolerate some cold but protect from hard freezes. Popular in China and Japan. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Evergreen fruit trees in the Sapindaceae family with sweet, fragrant fruits, require tropical or subtropical climate
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growing season. Well-drained, acidic soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in spring and summer with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile but cross-pollination improves yield. Harvest when skin is pink-red and fruit is fragrant. Require tropical or subtropical climate - protect from frost. Very popular in China. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Smooth-skinned peaches in the Rosaceae family, genetic variant of peach, require winter chill
commonExamples: Prunus persica var. nucipersica (Nectarine), 'Fantasia', 'Red Gold', 'Arctic Glo', 'Sunraycer'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Smooth skin unlike peaches. Thin fruit for larger nectarines. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when fully colored. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with fuzzy skin and sweet flesh, require winter chill
commonExamples: Prunus persica (Peach), freestone and clingstone varieties, 'Elberta', 'Redhaven', 'Georgia Belle'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties are self-fertile. Thin fruit for larger peaches. Protect from late frosts during flowering. Harvest when easily twists off branch. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with sweet, juicy flesh, most varieties need cross-pollination
commonExamples: Pyrus communis (European pear), P. pyrifolia (Asian pear), 'Bartlett', 'Bosc', 'Anjou', 'Asian' varieties
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Most varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties. Harvest when mature but still firm - ripen off tree. Requires winter chill. Research specific type (European vs Asian) for exact requirements. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Ebenaceae family, astringent and non-astringent varieties, popular in both USA and China
commonExamples: Diospyros kaki (Asian persimmon), D. virginiana (American persimmon), 'Fuyu', 'Hachiya'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Most varieties are self-fertile. Harvest astringent varieties when very soft; non-astringent when firm. Popular in both USA and China. Requires winter chill for best fruiting. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Rosaceae family with smooth skin, many varieties need cross-pollination
commonExamples: Prunus domestica (European plum), P. salicina (Japanese plum), 'Santa Rosa', 'Methley', 'Stanley'
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Increase watering during fruit development. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with fruit tree fertilizer. Prune in late winter/early spring. Many varieties need cross-pollination - plant compatible varieties. Thin fruit for larger plums. Harvest when fully colored and slightly soft. Requires winter chill. Reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Deciduous fruit trees in the Lythraceae family with jewel-like seeds, drought-tolerant once established
careTips: Deep soak weekly during growing season. Drought tolerant once established. Mulch around base. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune to maintain shape. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully colored and makes metallic sound when tapped. Can be grown in containers. Requires hot summers for best fruiting. Deciduous; reduce or withhold watering when leaves drop in fall.

description: Large citrus fruits in the Rutaceae family, largest citrus fruit, popular in China and Southeast Asia
careTips: Deep soak regularly during growing season. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun essential. Fertilize monthly spring through fall with citrus fertilizer. Prune to maintain size. Self-fertile. Harvest when fully yellow and fragrant. Largest citrus fruit. Require warm climates - protect from frost. Popular in China and Southeast Asia. Evergreen; reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial cane fruits in the Rosaceae family, produce fruit on second-year canes (floricane) or first-year canes (primocane) depending on variety
commonExamples: Rubus idaeus (Red raspberry), R. occidentalis (Black raspberry), R. leucodermis (Blackcap raspberry), summer-bearing and everbearing varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (weekly deep watering). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit. Mulch around plants to retain moisture and suppress weeds. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring with balanced fertilizer. Prune according to type - summer-bearing: remove fruited canes after harvest; everbearing: can be pruned for one or two crops. Support canes with trellis. Harvest when fully colored and easily detaches. Replace plants every 8-10 years. Deciduous varieties: reduce watering when dormant in winter.

description: Low-growing perennial berry plants in the Rosaceae family, produce runners for propagation
commonExamples: Fragaria × ananassa (Garden strawberry), June-bearing, everbearing, and day-neutral varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting fruit which can cause rot. Mulch with straw or pine needles to keep berries clean and prevent soil contact. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize in early spring and after harvest with balanced fertilizer. Remove runners first year to encourage fruiting; allow runners second year to propagate. Harvest when fully red. Replace plants every 3-4 years. Research variety type (June-bearing, everbearing, day-neutral) for exact requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Annual culinary herb in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, essential in Mediterranean and Asian cuisines
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Sweet basil, Genovese basil), O. basilicum 'Purple', O. tenuiflorum (Holy basil, Tulsi), Thai basil
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Water at base to avoid wetting leaves. Well-drained soil essential. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Pinch flowers immediately to prolong leaf production. Harvest regularly by pinching tips to encourage bushy growth. Very sensitive to cold - plant after last frost. Annual - replant each season.

description: Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with flat leaves and garlic flavor, essential in Chinese cuisine
commonExamples: Allium tuberosum (Chinese chives, Garlic chives, Gow choy, Nira)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Garlic flavor. Essential in Chinese cuisine. Can be grown in containers. Edible white flowers. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Perennial herbs in the Amaryllidaceae family with hollow, grass-like leaves, easy to grow
commonExamples: Allium schoenoprasum (Chives), common chives, garlic chives (Allium tuberosum)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest by cutting leaves at base. Divide every 3-4 years. Perennial - returns each year. Easy to grow. Can be grown in containers. Edible purple flowers. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Annual herb in the Apiaceae family, leaves (cilantro) and seeds (coriander) are both used, bolts quickly in heat
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Consistent moisture prevents bolting. Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Prefer cooler temperatures - plant in spring or fall. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Bolts quickly in heat - provide shade in summer or plant in fall. Annual - replant each season. Seeds (coriander) can be harvested when brown.

description: Annual herbs in the Apiaceae family with feathery leaves and seeds, both leaves and seeds are used
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun essential. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest leaves regularly. Harvest seeds when brown. Can bolt in heat - plant in spring or fall. Both leaves and seeds are used. Attracts beneficial insects. Annual - replant each season.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, essential spice in Chinese cuisine, can be grown from store-bought rhizomes
commonExamples: Zingiber officinale (Ginger), common ginger, young ginger
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred - avoid direct hot sun. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces with eyes pointing up. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Essential spice in Chinese cuisine. Rhizomes can be harvested partially. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Culinary herbs grown indoors, require good drainage and regular harvesting to encourage bushy growth
commonExamples: Ocimum basilicum (Basil, Sweet basil), Mentha (Mint, Spearmint, Peppermint), Thymus (Thyme), Rosmarinus (Rosemary), Petroselinum (Parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Allow top inch to dry slightly between waterings. Avoid waterlogged soil - excellent drainage essential. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily minimum). Medium humidity (40-50%) is fine. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer at half strength. Harvest regularly to encourage bushy growth - pinch tips. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Repot annually. Research specific herb for exact requirements.

description: Perennial grasses in the Poaceae family with lemony flavor, popular in Asian cuisine, can be grown in containers
commonExamples: Cymbopogon citratus (Lemongrass, West Indian lemongrass), C. flexuosus (East Indian lemongrass)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Full sun preferred. Fertilize monthly with nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Harvest outer stalks at base. Divide every 2-3 years. Perennial in warm climates - treat as annual in cold. Can be grown in containers. Lemony flavor. Popular in Asian cuisine. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with aromatic leaves, can be invasive, spreads by runners
commonExamples: Mentha spicata (Spearmint), M. × piperita (Peppermint), M. suaveolens (Apple mint), M. × villosa (Apple mint)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Prefer consistently moist but well-drained soil. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Harvest regularly to control growth. Very invasive - grow in containers or use barriers to contain. Spreads by runners. Can be grown indoors or outdoors. Perennial but may die back in winter. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with pungent leaves, essential in Mediterranean cuisine
commonExamples: Origanum vulgare (Oregano, Wild marjoram), O. vulgare subsp. hirtum (Greek oregano), O. majorana (Sweet marjoram)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Pinch flowers to prolong leaf production. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Flavor intensifies when dried. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Biennial herbs in the Apiaceae family, most commonly used as annual, curly and flat-leaf varieties
commonExamples: Petroselinum crispum (Curly parsley), P. crispum var. neapolitanum (Flat-leaf parsley, Italian parsley)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist (2-3 times per week). Well-drained soil preferred. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize every 3-4 weeks with balanced fertilizer. Harvest outer leaves regularly to encourage new growth. Biennial but usually grown as annual. Flat-leaf has stronger flavor. Can be grown indoors. Very common culinary herb. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with gray-green leaves, drought-tolerant once established
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest leaves regularly. Prune to maintain shape. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Strong flavor - use sparingly in cooking. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Perennial herbs in the Lamiaceae family with small aromatic leaves, drought-tolerant once established
commonExamples: Thymus vulgaris (Common thyme, Garden thyme), T. citriodorus (Lemon thyme), T. serpyllum (Creeping thyme)
careTips: Water when soil is dry (every 1-2 weeks once established). Well-drained soil essential. Drought tolerant once established. Full sun preferred (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize sparingly in spring. Harvest regularly by cutting stems. Can be grown as groundcover or in containers. Perennial - may need protection in very cold climates. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Rhizomatous herbs in the Zingiberaceae family, related to ginger, popular spice and natural dye
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. Well-drained, rich soil preferred. Partial shade preferred. Fertilize monthly with balanced fertilizer. Plant rhizome pieces. Harvest when leaves die back (8-10 months). Can be grown in containers. Related to ginger. Popular spice and natural dye. Requires warm climate - protect from frost. Reduce watering in winter when growth slows.

description: Ornamental flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, include edible onions and ornamental varieties
commonExamples: Allium giganteum (Giant allium), A. aflatunense (Persian onion), A. schubertii (Schubert's allium), A. christophii (Star of Persia)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall. Full sun preferred. Well-drained soil essential. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Ornamental varieties have large, spherical flower heads. Naturalize well. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Deterrent to many pests. Perfect for borders and cut flowers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Large flowering bulbs in the Amaryllidaceae family, popular for indoor winter forcing, can rebloom with proper care
commonExamples: Hippeastrum (Amaryllis), various colors and cultivars, single and double varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during active growth and flowering. Reduce watering after flowering as foliage dies back. For forcing: plant in fall, keep in cool dark place until shoots appear, then move to bright light. For outdoor: plant in spring in warm climates. Bright indirect to direct light. Fertilize monthly during active growth. Can rebloom with proper dormancy care. Large, showy flowers. Perfect for holiday displays.

description: Early spring flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family, among first flowers to bloom, naturalize well
commonExamples: Crocus vernus (Spring crocus), C. chrysanthus (Golden crocus), C. sativus (Saffron crocus), C. tommasinianus (Tommasini's crocus)
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry naturally after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Among first flowers to bloom in spring. Naturalize well - will spread over time. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for naturalizing in lawns or under trees. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Amaryllidaceae family, planted in fall, naturalize well and are deer-resistant
commonExamples: Narcissus (Daffodil, Jonquil), N. pseudonarcissus (Wild daffodil), trumpet, large-cupped, small-cupped, double, and miniature varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 4-6 inches deep. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally - don't cut until yellow. Naturalize well and multiply over time. Deer and rodent resistant. Excellent for naturalizing in lawns and gardens. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Summer flowering bulbs in the Iridaceae family with tall spikes of colorful flowers, excellent for cut flowers
commonExamples: Gladiolus × hortulanus (Garden gladiolus), various colors and sizes, dwarf and standard varieties
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (summer). Plant corms in spring after last frost. Full sun essential (6-8 hours daily). Fertilize when shoots emerge and during flowering. Stake tall varieties. Lift corms in fall in cold climates and store over winter. Allow foliage to die back before lifting. Excellent for cut flowers. Plant in succession for continuous blooms. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Fragrant spring flowering bulbs in the Asparagaceae family, can be forced indoors or grown outdoors
commonExamples: Hyacinthus orientalis (Common hyacinth, Dutch hyacinth), various colors and cultivars
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering. Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes). Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize when shoots emerge. Very fragrant flowers. Can be forced indoors with pre-chilling. Naturalize slowly. Allow foliage to die back naturally. Perfect for spring borders and containers. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Bulbous perennial flowering plants in the Liliaceae family with showy trumpet-shaped or recurved flowers, many are fragrant
commonExamples: Lilium (Lily, Easter lily, Oriental lily, Asiatic lily), L. longiflorum (Easter lily), L. orientalis (Oriental lily), L. asiaticum (Asiatic lily), L. candidum (Madonna lily)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist during growth and flowering (spring-summer). Allow to dry slightly after flowering. Well-drained soil essential - avoid waterlogged conditions. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Plant bulbs in fall or early spring. Mulch to keep roots cool. Remove spent flowers but leave foliage until yellow. Divide bulbs every 3-4 years. Many are fragrant. Research specific type for exact requirements. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Spring-blooming bulbous perennials in the Liliaceae family, planted in fall for spring flowers, many varieties available
commonExamples: Tulipa (Tulip), T. gesneriana (Garden tulip), single early, double early, triumph, Darwin hybrid, parrot, and fringed varieties
careTips: Keep soil moist during growth and flowering (spring). Allow to dry after foliage dies back. Plant bulbs in fall (6-8 weeks before ground freezes) with pointed end up, 6-8 inches deep. Full sun preferred. Fertilize when shoots emerge and after flowering with bulb fertilizer. Allow foliage to die back naturally to feed bulbs - don't cut until yellow. Many varieties are treated as annuals in warm climates. Research variety type for exact requirements and bloom time. Bulbs go dormant after flowering; reduce watering when foliage dies back.

description: Plants that grow fully or partially submerged in water, include floating, submerged, and emergent types
commonExamples: Nymphaea (Water lily), Nelumbo (Lotus, Sacred lotus), Eichhornia (Water hyacinth), Pistia (Water lettuce)
careTips: Fully submerged or floating in water - no soil watering needed. Maintain water quality - clean, oxygenated water essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets placed in soil or water. Remove dead leaves and flowers regularly. Control algae growth. Some species are invasive - check local regulations. Water depth varies by species. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Perfect for ponds and water gardens. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Plants adapted to constantly wet or waterlogged soil, ideal for water gardens and pond edges
commonExamples: Cyperus papyrus (Papyrus, Egyptian paper reed), Canna (Canna lily), Iris pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), Sagittaria (Arrowhead)
careTips: Keep soil constantly moist or waterlogged - never allow to dry out. Can grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches). Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Ideal for water gardens and pond edges. Some species spread aggressively - contain with barriers. Remove dead foliage. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Adapted to constantly wet conditions. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Emergent wetland plants in the Typhaceae family, grow in shallow water or wet soil, can be invasive
commonExamples: Typha latifolia (Common cattail, Broadleaf cattail), T. angustifolia (Narrowleaf cattail), T. domingensis (Southern cattail)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (6-12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun preferred. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Spreads aggressively by rhizomes - contain with barriers or grow in containers. Remove seed heads to prevent spread. Can be invasive - check local regulations. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Aquatic plants grown indoors in water containers or hydroponic setups
commonExamples: Dracaena sanderiana (Lucky bamboo), Pothos in water, Philodendron in water, Spider plant in water
careTips: Keep roots submerged in water at all times. Change water weekly to prevent stagnation and algae growth. Use filtered or distilled water to avoid mineral buildup. Bright indirect light preferred. Add liquid fertilizer monthly at quarter strength. Clean container monthly. Some plants can transition from soil to water. Perfect for hydroponic setups or decorative water containers. Research specific plant for exact requirements. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Sacred aquatic plants in the Nelumbonaceae family with beautiful flowers and edible roots, important in Chinese culture
commonExamples: Nelumbo nucifera (Lotus, Sacred lotus, Indian lotus), various colors and sizes
careTips: Grow in shallow to deep water (6-24 inches). Never allow to dry out. Full sun essential. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer tablets. Plant tubers in spring. Beautiful flowers bloom above water. Edible roots (lotus root), seeds, and leaves. Can be invasive - contain with barriers. Important in Chinese culture and Buddhism. Requires water garden or pond. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Aquatic vegetables from lotus plants in the Nelumbonaceae family, popular in Chinese cuisine, grow in water
commonExamples: Nelumbo nucifera (Lotus, Sacred lotus), roots are harvested for food
careTips: Grow in shallow water (6-12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun essential. Fertilize with aquatic plant fertilizer. Harvest roots when mature (fall). Popular in Chinese cuisine. Can be invasive - contain with barriers. Beautiful flowers. Requires water garden or pond. Research specific growing requirements. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Emergent aquatic plants in the Pontederiaceae family with spikes of blue flowers, ideal for pond margins
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 12 inches) or constantly wet soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Spreads by rhizomes - may need containment. Remove spent flowers to prevent self-seeding. Perfect for pond margins and water gardens. Attracts pollinators. Provides wildlife habitat. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Iris species adapted to wet conditions, grow in shallow water or boggy soil, ideal for water gardens
commonExamples: Iris laevigata (Japanese water iris), I. pseudacorus (Yellow flag iris), I. versicolor (Blue flag iris)
careTips: Grow in shallow water (up to 6 inches) or constantly wet, boggy soil. Never allow to dry out. Full sun to partial shade. Fertilize monthly during growing season with aquatic plant fertilizer. Divide every 3-4 years to maintain vigor. Remove dead foliage. Perfect for pond edges and water gardens. Some species can be invasive - check local regulations. Aquatic; winter care varies by Hardiness Zone.

description: Carnivorous plants in the Lentibulariaceae family with sticky leaves that trap insects, include temperate and tropical species
commonExamples: Pinguicula (Butterwort), P. vulgaris (Common butterwort), P. moranensis (Mexican butterwort), temperate and tropical species
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Sticky leaves trap small insects. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Unique carnivorous plant in the Sarraceniaceae family native to California and Oregon, requires cool conditions
commonExamples: Darlingtonia californica (Cobra lily, California pitcher plant, Darlingtonia)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Prefer cool conditions - avoid heat. Bright indirect to direct light. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter. Unique cobra-like appearance. Very challenging to grow outside native range.

description: Carnivorous plants with modified leaves forming pitcher-shaped traps, include temperate and tropical species
commonExamples: Sarracenia (North American pitcher plant), Nepenthes (Tropical pitcher plant, Monkey cups), Darlingtonia (Cobra lily)
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60-70%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Fill pitchers with water if they dry out. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Carnivorous plants in the Droseraceae family with sticky, dewy leaves that trap insects
commonExamples: Drosera (Sundew), D. capensis (Cape sundew), D. rotundifolia (Round-leaved sundew), temperate and tropical species
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water. Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Bright indirect to direct light depending on species. High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Temperate species require dormancy; tropical species do not. Dewy appearance indicates healthy plant. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: Most famous carnivorous plant in the Droseraceae family, native to North Carolina, requires dormancy and pure water
careTips: Constant moisture with distilled or rainwater ONLY - never tap water (minerals kill them). Keep in tray of water (1-2 inches deep). Reduce watering in winter dormancy but keep slightly moist. Bright indirect to direct light (4-6 hours daily). High humidity (60%+) preferred. Use only sphagnum peat moss or specialized carnivorous plant soil. Don't fertilize - they get nutrients from insects. Require dormancy period in winter (cooler temperatures, reduced light). Don't trigger traps unnecessarily - each trap can only close a few times.

description: Epiphytic plants in the Bromeliaceae family that grow without soil, absorb water and nutrients through their leaves
commonExamples: Tillandsia (Air plant), T. ionantha (Sky plant), T. xerographica (King of air plants), T. usneoides (Spanish moss)
careTips: Soak weekly for 20-30 minutes in room temperature water. Mist 2-3 times per week between soaks. Shake off excess water after soaking - water left in center causes rot. Ensure good air circulation - never keep in closed containers. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50%+) preferred. Fertilize monthly by adding fertilizer to soak water at quarter strength. Grow without soil - mount on wood, rocks, or display in air. Research specific species for exact requirements.

description: General category for plants that grow on other plants - see specific categories (Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants) for detailed care
careTips: Mist regularly (daily to weekly depending on species). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Ensure good drainage - never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood, bark, or in specialized epiphyte mix. Good air circulation essential. Research specific plant type for exact requirements - see Orchids, Bromeliads, Air Plants for detailed care.

description: Non-vascular bryophytes that require constant moisture and high humidity, absorb water through leaves
commonExamples: Sheet moss, Sphagnum moss (Peat moss), Fern moss, Cushion moss, Haircap moss
careTips: Mist daily or multiple times per day to maintain constant moisture. Never allow to dry out completely - even brief drying can kill moss. High humidity (80%+) essential - use terrarium or enclosed space. Bright indirect to low light preferred; direct sun dries moss quickly. Use distilled or rainwater - tap water minerals can harm moss. Acidic conditions preferred. Perfect for terrariums and moss gardens. Very challenging to maintain outside natural habitat.

description: Large family of epiphytic and terrestrial plants in the Orchidaceae family, many are popular houseplants with specific care needs
commonExamples: Phalaenopsis (Moth orchid), Cattleya, Dendrobium, Oncidium, Paphiopedilum (Lady's slipper), many genera and species
careTips: Water when potting medium is nearly dry (weekly to bi-weekly). Never let sit in water. Bright indirect light preferred - avoid direct sun. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with orchid fertilizer at quarter strength. Use specialized orchid potting mix (bark, sphagnum moss). Repot every 2-3 years. Good air circulation essential. Many species are epiphytic. Research specific genus for exact requirements.

description: Epiphytic fern in the Polypodiaceae family that can survive extreme drought by curling up and appearing dead
commonExamples: Pleopeltis polypodioides (Resurrection fern, formerly Polypodium polypodioides)
careTips: Mist regularly (2-3 times per week). Soak mounted plants weekly for 15-30 minutes. Can survive drought by curling up - will revive when watered. Bright indirect light preferred. High humidity (50-70%) preferred. Fertilize monthly with diluted fertilizer. Grow without soil - mount on wood or bark. Good air circulation essential. Epiphytic - grows on trees in nature. Very drought tolerant for a fern.

description: Plants adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions with excellent drainage, many are drought tolerant
commonExamples: Saxifraga (Saxifrage), Sempervivum (Hens and chicks), Dianthus (Pinks, Carnations), Gentiana (Gentian), Androsace (Rock jasmine)
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil which causes root rot. Full sun preferred. Many are drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens. Adapted to high-altitude, rocky conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Mat-forming alpine perennial in the Brassicaceae family with masses of spring flowers, excellent for rock gardens
commonExamples: Aubrieta deltoidea (Aubrieta, Rock cress), various cultivars and colors
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun preferred. Drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Shear after flowering to maintain shape. Mat-forming habit. Masses of spring flowers. Perfect for rock gardens, walls, and slopes. Very cold hardy. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Iconic alpine plant in the Asteraceae family with woolly white flowers, symbol of the Alps, requires excellent drainage
commonExamples: Leontopodium nivale (Edelweiss, Alpine edelweiss), L. alpinum
careTips: Light watering (every 1-2 weeks). Allow to dry between waterings. Excellent drainage essential - use rocky, gritty soil mix. Avoid waterlogged soil. Full sun preferred. Very drought tolerant once established. Fertilize sparingly if at all. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Challenging to grow outside alpine conditions. Symbol of the Alps. Requires cool summers. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Alpine and woodland plants in the Gentianaceae family with intense blue flowers, prefer cool, moist conditions
commonExamples: Gentiana (Gentian), G. acaulis (Stemless gentian), G. septemfida (Crested gentian), G. sino-ornata (Chinese gentian)
careTips: Keep soil evenly moist but well-drained. Prefer cool, moist conditions. Excellent drainage essential. Full sun to partial shade depending on species. Fertilize sparingly in spring. Perfect for rock gardens and alpine gardens. Many species are challenging to grow. Adapted to high-altitude conditions. Research specific species for exact requirements. Alpine; reduce watering when dormant; avoid winter wet.

description: Shade-tolerant flowering plant with strap-like leaves and striking orange or yellow flower clusters.
commonExamples: Clivia miniata (Kaffir lily, Bush lily), C. nobilis
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Needs a cool, dry rest period (6-8 weeks in fall) with minimal watering to trigger blooming. Bright indirect light preferred; tolerates low light. Keep slightly pot-bound to encourage flowering. Fertilize monthly spring through summer. Toxic to pets.

description: Compact umbrella plant with palmate leaves, easier to manage indoors than the larger schefflera.
commonExamples: Schefflera arboricola (Dwarf umbrella plant, Hawaiian elf schefflera), S. arboricola 'Variegata'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Medium humidity fine. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to maintain shape. More compact than standard schefflera. Toxic to pets.

description: Bold tropical foliage plant with large, deeply lobed palmately compound leaves.
commonExamples: Fatsia japonica (Japanese aralia, Paper plant), F. japonica 'Spider Web'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light; tolerates lower light. High humidity preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Can grow large; prune to control size. Toxic to pets.

description: Ficus with glossy oval leaves, popular for bonsai; can develop aerial roots.
commonExamples: Ficus microcarpa (Chinese banyan, Ginseng ficus, Banyan fig), F. microcarpa 'Green Island'
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Often grown as bonsai. Avoid moving once established. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Toxic to pets.

description: Conifer-like evergreen with narrow leaves, popular for bonsai and topiary.
commonExamples: Podocarpus macrophyllus (Buddhist pine, Kusamaki, Yew pine), P. henkelii
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light. Tolerates lower light. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Prune to maintain shape. Good for bonsai. Toxic to pets.

description: Ancient cycad (not a true palm) with feathery fronds emerging from a woody trunk.
commonExamples: Cycas revoluta (Sago palm, King sago), C. circinalis
careTips: Water when top half of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Slow-growing; very long-lived. Fertilize 2-3 times per year. Highly toxic to pets and humans - handle with care.

description: Popular houseplant in the Tree Philodendron family.
careTips: Water when top inch of soil is dry. Bright indirect light preferred. Fertilize monthly spring through fall. Repot every 1-2 years when roots fill container.

description: Perennial vegetable with tender edible spears, takes 2-3 years to establish.
careTips: Water regularly during growing season. Full sun. Rich, well-drained soil. Do not harvest first year; light harvest second year. Mulch in winter. Long-lived perennial. Herbaceous perennials die back; reduce watering when dormant.

description: Allium with mild edible green tops and white bases, used fresh in many cuisines.
commonExamples: Allium fistulosum (Welsh onion, Bunching onion), A. cepa 'Evergreen'
careTips: Keep soil moist. Full sun. Fast-growing. Harvest when tops are 6-8 inches. Can regrow from roots. Popular in Asian cooking. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Evergreen shrub whose leaves produce black, green, oolong, and white tea.
commonExamples: Camellia sinensis (Tea plant, Tea shrub), C. sinensis var. assamica
careTips: Acidic soil (pH 4.5-5.5). Partial shade in hot climates. Avoid hard frost. Harvest young leaves (two leaves and a bud). Prune to encourage bush growth.

description: Climbing orchid that produces vanilla beans; requires hand-pollination and warm, humid conditions.
commonExamples: Vanilla planifolia (Vanilla orchid, Flat-leaved vanilla), V. tahitensis
careTips: High humidity (70%+). Warm temperatures. Bright indirect light. Provide support to climb. Hand-pollinate flowers for bean production. Takes years to flower.

description: Spice plant in the ginger family with aromatic seeds used in cooking and chai.
commonExamples: Elettaria cardamomum (Green cardamom, True cardamom), Amomum subulatum (Black cardamom)
careTips: Keep soil consistently moist. High humidity. Partial shade. Warm temperatures. Harvest seed pods when green and before splitting. Tropical perennial.

description: Tender squash (mirliton) with edible fruit, shoots, and roots; vigorous vine.
commonExamples: Sechium edule (Chayote, Mirliton, Vegetable pear, 佛手瓜)
careTips: Full sun. Provide strong trellis. Keep soil moist. Harvest when fruit is 4-6 inches. Young shoots and roots also edible. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Starchy root crop (corm) staple in Pacific and Asian cuisines; leaves and corms must be cooked before eating.
careTips: Wet or very moist soil. Partial sun. Warm temperatures. Harvest when leaves yellow. All parts contain calcium oxalate - must cook before eating. Toxic raw. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.

description: Gourd vine; young fruit edible as vegetable; mature fruit dries into natural sponge.
commonExamples: Luffa aegyptiaca (Egyptian luffa), L. acutangula (Angled luffa, 丝瓜)
careTips: Full sun. Strong trellis. Water regularly. Harvest young for food (under 6 inches). Let mature and dry on vine for sponge. Long growing season. Seasonal crop; watering varies by growing zone and harvest timing.
